title: bounce back from lockdown britain
story: IT’S high time Britain bounced back from lockdown — and The Sun aims to help you lead the way.With shops reopening, sport relaunching and families joyfully reuniting from next week, our major new Bounce Back Britain campaign intends to put people, communities and businesses back on their feet.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesWith practical advice, detailed guides and a host of money-­saving offers we’ll be with Sun readers every step of the way as you put your le back together — and start spending to help our economy mend too.Boris Johnson’s lockdown has saved countless lives and spared the NHS from being overwhelmed. But it has come at a huge cost. Le hasn’t been the same without our pubs, shops, restaurants and cinemas, our live football and racing  . . . and the simple pleasure of meeting friends and family. And let us be under no illusion over how grim things now look economically. The latest OECD forecast says we will be hit harder than any other major economy, with our growth down a staggering . per cent during  — worse, it says,a second Covid wave hits.It predicts  per cent of us will be jobless within about three months. In February it was just . per cent.The OECD routinely underestimates our resilience. But there is no doubt hundreds of thousands of small businesses, the leblood of our economy, are in peril. Large firms face losing huge numbers of staff. Thousands of jobs are being cut every day even though the Government is borrowing vast sums to preserve as many as it can. Yes, shops open on Monday. But our pubs, restaurants and hotels still sit idle. Kids are mainly still off school, at a ­catastrophic cost both to their education and the economy.The Sun has done its bit throughout this crisis by raising £million for our heroic NHS workers via our Who Cares Wins appeal and by keeping millions of readers up to date — and we have been praised for our detailed coverage. With our Bounce Back Britain campaign we’re going to step that up and add a practical helping hand. First things first. This weekend we will celebrate the relaunching of live sport, including Premier League action from June , with theof our Goals pullout, plus Ascot racing specials all next week and free bets. We’ll kick it off on Saturday with a bumper competition to win an entertainment bundle from Sky VIP worth over £,, including TVs, iPhones and Sky packages. Before next Monday, we will bring you a full guide to which shops are back open, how to socially distance as you go, and the best deals. Remember, you won’t just be glad to be flashing the cash again, you’ll be providing a public service too!So many High Street businesses badly need our support —  and we’ll hear from some of those owned by Sun readers.For those who have sadly lost their livelihoods in the lockdown, we’ll have advice on jobs, finances and CV-writing plus a bumper SunEmployment special offering thousands of vacancies.When it comes to entertainment we’ll have guides to what’s open, the best pubs with outside space, which theme parks are operating — and free ticket offers. Football is back and, oh, how the country has missed its sporting heroes fighting it out in the Premier League. Britain’s No racing ­pullout is already up and running.Favourite is under starter’s orders every Saturday and the top tips, form and all the best racing writers will be inside the paper every day during Royal Ascot next week – plus we’ll be ­giving away great FREE bets.And don’t forget Test cricket, Formula , ­boxing and all the other key sports ing to action in The Sun this month.WE all deserve to let our hair  down after the past few months.And as the nation’s pubs, bars, ­restaurants, zoos and theme parks  finally reopen, we will be there with the deals you need to enjoy amazing attractions at the very best prices.From great  days out to perfect pub gardens, we will get your social le back on track in style.In the coming weeks our brilliant Sun Superdays ­promotions will be ing, giving readers the chance to get their hands on FREE tickets to some of the country’s top theme parks. Our much-loved ­promotion will give you the chance to enjoy family fun at top attractions including Alton Towers Resort, LEGOLAND Windsor and Thorpe Park Resort plus more. And we will bring you brilliant guides to the best summer holiday fun around the UK.Bounce Back Britain will help you to start enjoying fun days out again in a safe way.And, as always, we will be  first with the exclusives on all your favourite telly shows to keep you entertained indoors, together with the latest news on gigs and cinema releases as they . title: prince andrew jeffery epstein talk fbi
story: Surely you would do anything you could to bring those responsible to justice. So it is extremely confusing why Prince Andrew is resisting demands to meet US officials probing convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein and his associates.Department of Justice investigators want to speak to Andrew as a witness. Jeffrey Epstein killed himself in August last year, taking many of his depraved secrets to the grave.Despite this, Andrew has, according to US prosecutors, “repeatedly declined” a request to be interviewed and had “unequivocally” stated he would not come in for one.Instead, his lawyers say he has offered to provide a witness statement, which is not quite the same.Although I guess he knows that already, having submitted to the car crash Newsnight interview with Emily Maitlis, during which he kept digging the hole he was in.If Andrew has got nothing to hide about his relationship with Jeffery Epstein, why did he request to communicate with the FBI through a written statement Friends of the duke this week claimed he was “utterly bewildered” by accusations that he was refusing to help US investigators.But it all just feels a bit . . . murky, doesn’t it He should jump at the chance of properly explaining his relationship with Epstein and his close friend Ghislaine Maxwell.She has been accused of acting as a pimp for Epstein — which her lawyers have denied — and has vanished.No doubt the duke has spent the past few months hoping this story will just go away, or be eclipsed by other, bigger news events. But clearly, this story is going nowhere.The bottom line is thatthe authorities in the US want to interview him, he must speak to them.Then he can repair his reputation and that of the wider Royal Family.He needs to restore the public’s trust in him. In his Newsnight interview he referred to himself, repeatedly, as “honourable”.Well, now is the time to prove it. Just step up, do the FBI interview and get it over and done with.And in all of this furore, let’s not forget Epstein’s victims. If Prince Andrew can shed any light on Epstein, who killed himself before he could go to trial for new sex trafficking charges, then why won’t he Perhaps he feels that, as a member of the Royal Family, he should not be subject to the same kind of scrutiny as “ordinary” people.But that line of thinking won’t cut the mustard in light of the seriousness of the allegations about Epstein — and those who benefitted from spending time with him.Anyone who watched the documentary about victim Virginia Roberts, Epstein and Prince Andrew will agree that it seems unlikely that anyone who knew Epstein would have known something was not right.I knowI had seen what is alleged, I would have walked straight out and to the first police station.But perhaps he can persuade prosecutors otherwise. And anyway, what is plain to see is that Andrew will only get his le back once he has answered some questions and cleared his name.In the meantime, though, I have another, possibly more pressing question that I would like answered: Where the hell has Ghislaine Maxwell disappeared to, and why is she not being interviewed about her role in all of this A good education closes the gap between the advantaged and the disadvantaged. The better your education, the more career choices you have.So when schools closed in March and we were all told to stay at home, a plan for how to reopen them should have been an absolute priority from day one.But schools are still closed to most children – indefinitely and with no firm or credible plan for them to reopen, even in September.We can go to Thorpe Park. We can go to Ikea. But our children cannot go to school.In the meantime, an estimated , kids are currently doing no school-work at all.No one disagrees that lockdown should have included schools. But they need to reopen as soon as it is safe to do so.That might mean cutting class sizes from  to . It might mean half-days for children or twice as many classrooms and teachers, plus proper arrangements for social-distancing.These things all need managing and organising. So why don’t schools ask local business leaders to help with the logistics This is a national crisis and it is turning into a national emergency, as the gulf between the haves and have-nots widens.Of course, some families will not be comfortable sending their children to school. If that is the case, it should be their choice not to send them.But we need to get schools open again, fast.I had a little chuckle while reading the interview with Oscar-winning actress Cate Blanchett.With her four children and long-standing marriage, she seemingly has it all.But I loved her honesty about the reality of home-schooling her kids while also trying to work during lockdown.Cate said: “I know, as a working mother who identies as a feminist . . . it’s a very rare partnership where the men also accept that responsibility in making things work.”She added that her husband, Andrew Upton, bought her a vacuum cleaner for their first anniversary and has also given her a mixer and an ironing board.It could have been me talking, except I wasn’t given a vacuum cleaner.I was given a frying pan.A hospital costs about £million but without doctors and nurses there is no point.So perhaps I would suggest the money goes towards emergency funding to train hospital staff.What would NOT be on my list, though, is a new royal yacht. Yet that is exactly what former trade minister Lord Digby Jones has called for, to lt the nation’s spirits in the wake of the Covid- lockdown.Somehow, I doubt the Queen – who famously uses Tupperware to keep her breakfast cereal fresh – would agree that a new yacht is what is needed in these tough economic times.She might deserve it but wouldn’t want it.There are so many reasons to love the flute-playing American rapper Lizzo.This week she gave us another, with a tweet showing footage of her working out in many dferent guises.A voiceover said: “I’ve been working out consistently for the past five years – and it may come as a surprise to some of y’all that I’m not working out to have your ideal body type.“I’m working out to have MY ideal body type.“And you know what that is  None of your fing business. Because I am beautul. I am strong. I do my job.”I love this message, which is true in so many ways. I really hope women, young and old, take note. Love yourself and, seriously, don’t give a rat’s a what anyone  thinks.Litter – and worse.One green space near me has a sign up saying: “This is a park, not a toilet.”What happened to us during lockdown that we think it is OK to behave like this  Come on, people. We can do better.Having said that, maybe the council needs to put out some more bins.In the Nineties, it seemed barely a day went by without front-page shots of Kate Moss looking worse for wear after a night on the tiles.But those days are gone and there is something strangely comforting about Kate, who is now teetotal, needing to be in bed by pm so she gets her eight hours.Maybe that’s why she still looks so good. She spent years being there and doing that – now it’s time to get her beauty sleep.Not drinking has many benefits. I feel so much better at the end of Dry January than I do end after boozy December. Good for her.It was heartwarming to see Prince Philip in such fine fettle as he turned  last week.I love how dapper he still is. And he has good health, a strong marriage and great wit – le goals for all of us.I do hope he will be celebrating his th birthday – and beyond.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman hatches ducklings eggs waitrose
story: Charli Lello, , from Hertfordshire, put the Clarence Court eggs in an incubator as an experiment when she was furloughed from work.But a month later, she heard cheeping - and found the Braddock White ducklings starting to emerge from their shells.Shes named the little birds Beep, Peep and Meep.Charli, an assistant manager at a shop, told the BBC the ducklings would live a very happy le with her pet chickens.She first had the idea after seeing a video on Facebook of baby birds hatching from supermarket quail eggs.She said: While I was in Waitrose, I saw the duck eggs and thought maybe they would work as well. I was so excited for them to hatch but I still had in the back of my mind that these are supermarket eggs.They have been collected, bashed around on a delivery truck, then rattled around on a trolley onto a shelf, picked up and put down by who knows how many people, so they still might not go all the way.Charli was shocked when the ducklings did hatch - and said the experience with the cutest little balls of fluff had been amazing.The only reason I could try was because Im currently furloughed and have the time to raise them to an age where they wont need me all day, she said.Under normal circumstances it wouldnt have been possible or fair on them.A spokeswoman for Clarence Court Farms said: It is a feat of remarkably slim odds that a duckling has been hatched. But we acknowledge that its not impossible.Officials from Waitrose say fertilised eggs were safe to eat and entirely indistinguishable from normal eggs, unless incubated.Our farmers work hard to ensure ducks and drakes are separated correctly, the spokesperson said.As a result of this dficulty in sexing, a male white-feathered duck may very occasionally be left with a group of females, although, these instances are extremely rare.There may also be instances when a wild duck encounters farmed drakes, but again, this is rare.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus rules england uk lockdown shop reopening
story: But the UK lockdown following the coronavirus outbreak has resulted in big changes. Below is a breakdown of the new rules.Brits are now allowed to go clothes shopping, to the zoo or to places of worship for private prayer, as the rules officially changed this morning.Face coverings on public transport are also mandatory, meaning you might be denied travelyou’re not wearing one.In schools, meanwhile, more youngsters are allowed in – with older pupils welcomed back in smaller class sizes.But some of the strictest rules will stay in place, with pubs, bars, restaurants and hairdressers closed until July at the earliest, the two-metre rule still unchanged, and the -day quarantine for holidaymakers ing to the UK remaining in place.Here is everything you need to know about the upcoming coronavirus lockdown changes.On Wednesday, June , the Prime Minister announced that people living alone in England will be allowed to stay at someone ’s house from last weekend.Boris Johnson said that Brits who live on their own, or are a single parent with kids under , would be able to visit another household – of any size – without following social distancing rules.Speaking at the Downing Street press conference, the PM said: “All those in a support bubble will be able to act asthey live in the same household, meaning they can spend time together inside each others’ homes and do not need to stay two metres apart.However, Mr Johnson added that “support bubbles must be exclusive”, meaning you can’t change the household you are in a bubble with.There were . million people living alone in the UK last year, according to the Office for National Statistics, and the change could be a huge help for older people suffering from loneliness. Non-essential shops have reopened for the first time in almost three months today.Now, Brits can head out to buy clothes, furniture and kitchenware on the high street.Big brands reopening their branches include Argos, Debenhams, HM, Primark and John Lewis.However, there are plans in place for strict social distancing rules for shoppers.This will likely see one-way systems down the aisles, and limits on the number of customers allowed in store.You will need to wear a face coveringyou want to travel on public transport from today.Speaking in early June, Grant Shapps, the transport secretary, said that Brits could make their mask at home, and shouldn’t wear ones used in hospitals.He told the Downing Street press conference on June : “That doesn’t mean surgical masks, which we must keep for clinical settings. It means the kind of face covering you can easily make at home.”If you’re found not wearing a face covering, you might be refused travel and could face a fine of up to £ - or £paid in  days.There will be exceptions for young kids and disabled people.Also, all hospital visitors must wear face coverings from June .Zoos, safari parks and drive-in cinemas in England are allowed to reopen too.The announcement came amid fears that some zoos would be bankruptedforced to stay closed over the summer.Edward Perry, managing director of Knowsley Safari, in Merseyside, said while it was “very good news”, he wanted the park to have reopened sooner.He commented: “Knowsley Safari has been ready for the past week to safely open to the public and we still can’t understand why it’s been OK for people to jump in their cars to go and get Big Macs but not to come and see our big cats.”However, the Prime Minister has said that some zoo areas will still be off limits – in particular indoor areas like reptile houses.Places of worship across England also opened their doors today.But large gatherings will still not be allowed, meaning people can only pray while following social distancing rules.The Government has said that all churches will need to be cleaned regularly, and books cannot be shared.Places of worship havent been open since March , when lockdown began.There are also set to be some big changes in the classroom, with Year  and Year  pupils allowed back in waves.The Government has announced that only a quarter of kids will be allowed in school at a time – meaning that for some kids, they could get just one full day of teaching each week.Classrooms will have undergone some huge changes since March, with less desks, more frequent cleaning, and only minimal contact between pupils.When they’re not at school, children will still be required to complete remote learning, with the Government saying it should remain “the predominant mode of education”.Plans for other years toto the classroom have been delayed, with the Education Secretary last week saying that not all primary school kids will go back before summer.“We are not able to welcome all primary children back for a full month before the summer,” Gavin Williamson admitted on Tuesday.Some of the biggest changes are still to come, with bars and pubs still shut and the two-metre rule still being enforced.The Government has said that most other shops will be allowed to reopen from July  at the earliest – meaning Brits can get a proper haircut for the first time in months.Meanwhile, social distancing rules are currently under review, with the Government’s scientic advisers looking into whether it can be reduced.This would mean that shops, boozers and restaurants could let more customers in.Air bridges between the UK and other countries – which could see Brits allowed on summer holidays – are also yet to be agreed.Brits who go abroad now must self-isolate for two weeks when theyto the country.However, air bridges could be agreed by June , with Transport Secretary Grant Shapps saying last week that the Government is “actively working” on them.To receive The Suns Coronavirus title: lion bone trade south africa chinese medicines
story: Unfair Game, a new book by Lord Ashcroft, reveals the sickening practices carried out at  farms in South Africa where the big cats are bred and butchered for their skeletons.The cruel multi-million pound industry is fuelled by demand in China and South-East Asia for traditional medicines. In the new book, serialised in the " rel"noreferrer noopener"Mail on Sunday, it is revealed that some lions are deboned while they are still ALIVE because it gives the skeleton a lucrative pink colour – caused by blood being left in the bones. Unfair Game details a covert operation by security services, including ex-British soldiers, to expose the vile industry by using a dealer as an undercover “double agent.” One of the most serious claims by ex-Tory deputy chairman Lord Ashcroft is that the lions which are born into captivity are raised in such disgusting conditions that they could spread fatal diseases such as tuberculosis and botulism. Dr Peter Caldwell, a wildle vet in Pretoria, said botulism – an infection which attacks the nervous system – could spread to people through infected bones and skin. He said: “If that lion dies from botulism, the people who bred it won’t waste that animal by burying it or burning it. Instead, they will put it into the lion bone and skin trade. “And the toxin remains in the body, so the people who utilise that lion can die a miserable, painful death.”Other diseases spread by lion bones include brucellosis - an infection that causes arthritis and inflammation of the heart - and tuberculosis, which killed . million people globally in .Another shocking claim in the book is that a rich Russian paid one of the farms to let his bloodthirsty pack of hunting dogs savage one of the caged lions to death. When Lord Ashcroft’s lead investigator, who carried out an eight-month probe, presented his evidence to a South African police chief it was rejected and he was told he was “lucky” he was not in jail. The book estimates there are at least , lions, bred in captivity in South Africa, compared to just , in the wild. Sick farm bosses let wealthy hunters into the enclosures to kill the big cats for sport in so-called “canned hunts” which result in , lion deaths every year. Investigators also found that poachers hunt and kill wild lions in neighbouring Botswana by poisoning or shooting them in the stomachs to protect the precious bones. A lion skeleton is worth up to £,. And in sick markets in Johannesburg, lion bones and skins are sold alongside exotic animals such as pangolins – a creature which has been linked to Covid-.Lord Ashcroft writes: So are we sleep-walking straight into a new major public health crisis with the lion bone industry at its core  I fear we are. It could be a surge in a disease that already exists, or it could be a new and frightening infection, just like Covid- was.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince andrew regrets newsnight interview talk fbi olive branch
story: The prince was reported to have thought his televised sit-down had been a great success, but is now said to wish he had expressed more sympathy for the late paedophiles victims. The prince has long faced questions about his friendship with financier Epstein, who killed himself in August while awaiting trial on federal charges for the sex trafficking of minors. He was widely criticised for a November interview with the BBCs Emily Maitlis for, among other things, saying he didnt regret the association because it had helped him make contacts that proved useful for his work as a royal. Speaking to the Sunday Times, a source close to the duke said: “I don’t think he regrets the intention behind the interview, which was to clear the air for his family, the royal family and the institution. But the fact he was unable to appropriately or sufficiently convey his sympathy for the victims of Epstein, is of course a source of regret.”Virgina Roberts, who claims she had sex with Andrew aged  after being trafficked by Epstein, took to twitter to respond to the reports. Oh the gull of this toad - he regrets the BBC interview but not his friendship with Epstein because it gave him great contacts and much more, she wrote. This man is not a prince but a facet of insidiousness who has proven to get away with it all.Prince Andrew has always denied any wrongdoing. Recent weeks have also seen the princes legal team engage in a war of words with FBI prosecutors leading the probe into Epsteins crimes. Each side has publicly blamed the other for the fact Andrew is yet to be questioned at part of the investigation. It was reported last week that the US Department of Justice had submitted a formal request to the Home Office for assistance in speaking with Andrew as a witness. The dukes team responded by claiming he had offered his assistance as a witness to the DoJ on at least three occasions since the start of this year, and that the DoJ had breached its own confidentiality rules.Lead federal prosecutor Geoffrey Berman said in response that the prince ly [seeking to] portray himself to the public as eager and willing to cooperate. The prince has... repeatedly declined our request to schedule... an interview and nearly four months ago informed us unequivocally... that he would not come in for such an interview, Berman said.The duke is now reported to be unwilling to help with the probe unless US officials begin to work more honourably. title: kevin pietersen saving rhinos greater cricket england
story: And what a remarkable journey it has been too.For two decades Kevin was one of the world’s best cricketers, playing in  Test matches and  one-day internationals for England, and also captaining his adopted country.Yet seven years ago, shortly after he stopped playing for England, Kevin had what amounts to a “light-bulb moment” while back in South Africa, the country of his birth, when he suddenly realised he could use his worldwide fame to help endangered wildle.Like me, Kevin became angry and ashamed at the way some South Africans abuse big game purely for profit.While we share a passion for wildle, Kevin decided to concentrate his efforts on protecting endangered rhinos. My focus, however, has been on exposing those who raise captive-bred lions, either for their bones or as so-called “trophies” in “canned” hunts, where the lion — sometimes semi-tame and drugged — is shot in an enclosed area with no chance of escape.In an exclusive interview to mark the publication of my new book Unfair Game: An Exposé Of South Africa’s Captive-Bred Lion Industry, which is out tomorrow, Kevin, , spoke about his determination to make a dference.He said he is now prouder of his off-the-pitch exploits relating to wildle than of his cricketing achievements.“I am pleased that I found something that I am keen to do but also I think it is so much greater than any achievement I had on the cricket field,” he said.Sitting in a private room at the Wentworth Club in Surrey, close to his family home, Kevin told me that his love of wild animals stems from his childhood.He was born in Pietermaritzburg, South Africa, in  to an Afrikaner father and an English mother .He said: “A lot of people talk about ‘you are not born in Africa, Africa is born in you’, and that’s so true.“As an African kid, as a boy of the soil, I appreciated what was in the country. And wildle was right up there.”As a youngster, Kevin and his three brothers were taken on safari by his parents to the Kruger National Park in South Africa.“We saw some pretty amazing sights,” he said. His passion for wildle continued during his cricket career, when he often went on safari with family and friends to enjoy watching the “big five”  —  lion, leopard, rhino, elephant and African buffalo.However, his attitude to wildle underwent a major change when he travelled with two friends to South Africa in .Kevin said: “I had just finished with England. After playing a charity game, we went to a couple of safari lodges and went on a rhino micro-chipping experience, where you chip the horn for tracking purposes andthe rhino is poached. Only then did I appreciate what was happening to this beautul, iconic species.“So from  my focus and drive shted away from the international sporting buzz to a much-needed and much more necessary conservation plan. I realised quite what an issue rhino-poaching was, and I realised that I could make a dference by raising awareness, by raising money and by being a voice for an animal that has no voice.“So since  I have been banging the drum about what’s happening in Africa. I can’t tell you how many people now approach me to talk about conservation and not about cricket. The change has been fabulous. To sht from being identied as a familiar face through sport to going into a dferent world where people love animals is something I am incredibly proud of.”As well as establishing a luxury lodge on the edge of the Kruger National Park, Kevin has founded campaign group Save Our Rhino Africa India .It works to help prevent poaching for rhino horn, care for injured and orphaned rhino and to educate people about the fact that the five species of rhino face extinction, with fewer than , left in Africa and Asia.In Africa alone, there are fewer than , white rhinos and for black rhinos the number is below ,. Father-of-two Kevin, who is married to former Liberty X singer Jessica Taylor, spoke emotionally about his love for rhinos: “What is Africa without one of the ‘big five’  What is the world without one of the ‘big five’  That is why the rhino, which is crucially endangered, means so much to me. I just have this love affair with this animal that we are desperate to save.”Kevin is realistic when it comes to the occasional need to kill wild animals.While he strongly opposes trophy-hunting and the hunting of endangered species, he considers that hunting for food and culling wildle can both be legitimate in certain circumstances.“I am just a vocal campaigner on things I don’t think are right, whether it be bullying or plastics in the ocean or protecting wildle,” he said.Many of his strong views, including his anger towards trophy hunters, are aired on his Twitter feed, where he has .million followers.On Twitter, Kevin has highlighted my own wildle work.Last year, I revealed the full horrors of “lion farming” in South Africa, where some , captive lions are bred either for their bones — largely to serve an Asian market — or as “trophies”, most killed in the pretence of a “hunt”.In Africa, captive-bred lions now outnumber wild lions by around four to one. I asked Kevin whether he is ashamed of how some people in the country of his birth abuse lions, the so-called “King Of The Jungle.”He replied: “Absolutely right. I do not understand the end game, the end user, the person that pulls the trigger. I do not understand how you would want to take money out of your pocket to shoot an animal that has been born and raised to be shot.“I don’t understand the brain inside the head that says ‘Look at me in this photo’ [next to a dead wild animal — known as the ‘kill shot’]. It’s just not a space that I live in. It’s just not a world that I live in.“It’s pretty disgusting really to do such a thing. In this trophy photo, you see they [the so-called hunters] are smiling or laughing next to this majestic animal. For me it’s an absolute no-go.”Kevin said that he has long been aware that lion farming and canned hunting exist in South Africa. “It is something that can be stopped and should be stopped.“The human race doesn’t surprise me any more and that’s such a sad thing to say. There are some filthy people out there that don’t have any feeling for animals.”Like me, Kevin wants the UK Government to change the law so that body parts of endangered species can no longer be imported into the country.“I am  per cent against this importation,” he said.Kevin is disappointed the South African government and police have so far refused to act on information I supplied from two undercover investigations which I commissioned.These resulted in my team secretly filming, and eventually identying, many of those guilty of criminal offences. Yet Kevin is not that surprised by the inaction.“In all honestly, South Africa has such big issues — lack of electricity, blood-shedding, corruption within the government who have been looting the country for so many years, that I don’t think this wildle issue is high on their agendaI can be brutally honest,” he said, speaking shortly before the coronavirus pandemic.My respect for Kevin and his work is immense. Unlike many talented sportsman whose careers end because of age or injury, he has a real purpose to his le since retiring as a professional cricketer two years ago.“I did almost everything in the game of cricket, but being able to be a huge voice and a campaigner to try to keep a species alive is . . . something that I love,” he said. Kevin believes his work as a conservationist will be ongoing.“I don’t think it will ever be complete. Unfortunately these horrible people are seeing so much financial gain from killing these animals that it is going to take a lot of amazing people to constantly keep banging the drum to save our animals.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast high temperatures june monsoon downpours
story: Thunder and heavy rain could follow a balmy, warm weekend in parts of Britain after record temperatures this Spring.According to the Met Office, the rest of June will see heavy showers but with bouts of signicant sunshine and dry weather too.The week ahead will see temperatures remain in the mid-s, for much of the UK, with possible highs of C.Warm weather will continue tomorrow, with Nottingham enjoying temperatures of C, Carlisle of C and Southampton of C by the afternoon.Met Office forecaster Matthew Box said the beginning of next week will see warm temperatures continue while thundery showers pick up.He said: “Through much of this week – particularly through to Wednesday – we’re still expecting there to be this mix of sunny spells and heavy thundery downpours here and there.”The heavy showers will continue into the end of next week, with temperatures beginning to drop in the east of England – in places like Norwich and Hull.Brian Gaze, founder of forecaster The Weather Outlook, told Blowing Hot and Cold videochat that “June looks more flaming wet than flaming hot this year.”He added: “The European monsoon is seeing westerly winds , bringing rain, after being absent for much of a very dry spring.”The Met Offices Dr Box said that next weekend will see quite mixed weather, but heavy rain in some places.He said: “As we head towards next weekend, it does look like it’s going to be quite mixed, changeable, but showery conditions are likely to continue.“But, again we’re going to see some sunny spells as well. The showers could be heavy in places.”During the last week of June, however, the weather will take a turn for the worse - the Met Office meteorologist says it could become more “unsettled” with thundery downpours likely.Dr Box said: “And then, for the last full week of June, it does look like we could see some fairly unsettled weather with showers or longer spells of rain, with southern areas of the UK seeing some heavy spells of rain, possibly thundery as well.The downpours are likely to be heavier in summer months like June, because the warm weather creates more moisture in the air.Dr Box explained: “The heavier showers can be heavier in summer because of the preponderance of warmer air that’s available – moisture that’s available.“You need that moisture content to give the really heavy downpours, and that’s more readily available in summer when the air is warmer.“You can get heavy showers in the other months as well – but we all experience those more frequent thundery downpours through the summer monthswe get the right conditions because of the availability of warm air.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schools should ditch autumn exam plans
story: Repeat exams for kids who missed out on GCSEs and A levels this summer were due to take place in October for students unhappy with their grades this summer.But the NAHT union has called it “completely unreasonable” given the challenge of getting all pupils back to class for the next academic year.As some year  and  studentsto school they warn there is “no quick fix” to the damage done by the closures, as the government is set to announce more details on summer catch up schools this week.Paul Whiteman, general secretary of school leaders’ union NAHT called for the government to deliver a “detailed, coherent plan for September.He said: “It is vital that schools can focus on what is needed for their current students whether that is a phased reopening, improving remote learning or face to face teaching.“The proposal that all secondary schools will run an additional exam series in the autumn term is completely unreasonable in these circumstances.”Rubbishing the plan for summer catch up schools, he added: “Instead, we need a sustainable, long-term plan that draws on the wealth of knowledge within the profession about how to narrow achievement gaps, and serious consideration of a ‘catch-up premium’ to allow schools to focus on activities that are proven to work.”Amanda Spielman, Ofsted chief inspector, said many schools were being creative to help manage their class sizes and said dropping the two metre social distancing rule would mean more kids can go back to school.When asked whether reducing the two-metre social distancing guidelines would help schools accept more pupils, Ms Spielman said schools had been told there is a hierarchy of infection control, with handwashing placed higher than social distancing.She said: Social distancing within the bubbles of the half-size classes is, according to the guidance, an aspiration, not an absolute requirement.Whats really important is that everybody works to the guidance as it stands, plans for the relaxations that are likely to come along in future.But, yes, obviously, a reduced distance expectation will flow through into greater capacity in schools but what we need to get to is that plan for how we build capacity over time.Use relaxations as they come through but concentrate on the main objective which should surely be to get as many children back into school as possible and as soon as possible.Former Labour Prime Minister Tony Blair signed a letter calling for school kids on free school meals to get free internet at home.The proposal has been signed by over  MPs, former ministers and experts.Labour MP Siobhain McDonagh said: “The lockdown has exposed the digital ide in our society, with schools across the country reporting struggling families who do not have internet access at home.Those children who can’t access the same resources as their classmates will find themselves even further behind when they finally . Some may never catch up.“This policy isn’t a silver bullet and can’t replace months of missed education. But it would make an immediate, tangible dference to families right across our country.”GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: child obesity soar pupils six months off coronavirus
story: Fears have been raised that a lack of exercise could lead to weight gain for many, with one in five pupils already obese by the time they leave primary school. ⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThis month has seen children in certain age groups beginning toto school after months away during the lockdown. The government had previously said it wanted all primary school children tofor a month before the summer holidays, but the plans have now been dropped. Almost ten million children aged from reception to year ten will now be off school for at least six months between March and September.Russell Viner is the head of the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health and also serves on the Government’s Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies.“We need to get kids back to school as soon as we can for their health, he told the Mail. “Everybody in the nutritional world is concerned.“We talk endlessly about the risks of transmission of Covid, and that’s incredibly important, but it’s not the only thing.“The risk-balance equation for children is about the risks of not being in school and poor mental health, poor sleep and potentially lack of exercise and obesity.”Any impact on childrens weight will also be dficult to measure because the NHSs National Child Measurement programme, which monitors the height and weight of children in reception and year six, has been put on hold. Experts have previously found some evidence that childrens average weight tends to increase each year over the summer break, which is just six weeks long. Speaking on Wednesday, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that plans for schools tobefore the summer break had been dropped because the viruss infection rate “is not quite down far enough to change the social distancing measures in schools”.Head teachers association had previously said the plans would not be practicably possible, while teaching unions had raised concerns about the safety of pupils and staff. Running schools safely could mean reducing class sizes by up to a half, and the government is now under pressure to lay out a comprehensive plan for how it intends to see all pupils back by September. title: madeleine mccann cops preparing to search old wells at german paedo christian bs portuguese lair
story: Earlier this month, cops were reportedly preparing to dig up land around two Portuguese lairs where Christian B lived near Praia da Luz.One home, a farmhouse, is just  minutes walk from the hotel where the three-year-old went missing  years ago. The single-storey farmhouse property is littered with abandoned wells and sits on a hillside with a footpath to the beach where she played.Portuguese police were said yesterday to be considering searching the abandoned wells near the farmhouse, which was rented by Christian B.According to Portuguese newspaper Sol, the Judicial Policehas looked at the possibility Madeleines body could be in the wells. But Portuguese cops havent yet received a request from German authorities to search places frequented in the Algarve by Christian B, Sol reports.Christian B, , is in jail in Germany for drug dealing and is appealing a  conviction for a rape in .Another former home of Christian Bs is up in the hills above Praia da Luz on a secluded road surrounded by just a few other houses - a drive from there to the holiday club takes  minutes.In June , Scotland Yard detectives backed by a team of snfer dogs excavated scrubland around  yards from the farmhouse building, but unearthed no clues.The beauty spot is also well known to Madeleines parents Kate and Gerry McCann, who regularly jogged around Black Rock after launching their hunt for their daughter in Praia da Luz in May .A Portuguese source said: “Judicial Police have confirmed they have been approached by German authorities in connection with the case and they will undoubtedly be prepared to carry out fresh searches in the hope of giving the McCanns closure.“The obvious focus would be around the hillside former farm building and another property nearby with links to him.”Meanwhile, Christian Bs lawyers say he will refuse to answer questions because prosecutors must have proof he was involved in her disappearance, it is reported.Lawyer Friedrich Fulscher said: Mr B is remaining silent on the allegation at this time on the advice of his defence counsel. This is quite common in criminal proceedings.It is the duty of the state to prove that a suspect committed a crime. No accused person has to prove his innocence to the investigating authorities.And a former German police chief has admitted it was a huge mistake to noty Christian B in  that he was a person of interest in Madeleines disappearance.Cops in Braunschweig sent Christian B a summons seven years ago to appear for questioning in relation to the Madeleine case,Der Spiegelreported last Friday.There are fears the alleged blunder could have allowed him to destroy any evidence that may have existed, experts told the German newspaper.Ulf Kuch, the former head of police in the German city of Braunschweig, said sending the letter was a huge mistake.Mr Kuch said he didnt know about the Christian B summons despite his role at the time as supervisor for the officer who issued the notice, Thereported.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus press briefing time today june 15
story: Yet, face masks have also been made compulsory on public transport - and in the coronavirus press briefings this week, more could be revealed as the UK looks to phase out the restrictions.The press conferences are held at pm every weekday.They had been held on a daily basis since March , before recently stopping weekend briefings.The conferences are held at  Downing Street, with members of the media and public posing questions via video link after the opening statements.Downing Street have confirmed that Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab will lead todays press briefing.The First Secretary of State previously took over in running the Government during Prime Minister Boris Johnsons absence due to recovering from coronavirus.Raab will be joined by up to two fellow Government officials, normally medical or scientic professionals.Professor Chris Whitty, the Chief Medical Officer, and top scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance have joined on numerous occasions.Meanwhile, Professor Jonathan Van Tam, Dr Jenny Harries and NHSs national medical director for England, Stephen Powis has also regularly appeared.The press conference will be shown on most news channels, including BBC One and Sky News.You will also be able to catch it online on " href"https:www.bbc iplayer" target"_blank" rel"noreferrer noopener"BBC iPlayer.Alternatively, you can follow our dedicated live blog for all the latest information.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps revealed in the last press conference that the Government is working on travel corridors.These would allow Brits to go on holiday abroad this year without having to quarantine for  days upon their .He said: Thats something we’re actively working on.As Ive said before, air-bridges or travel corridors might be a potential way forward supplemented by things like testing.Theres clearly countries that have lower levels of infection but that may be they are yet to go into this rather than come out.We wont throw away the good work thats been done [to get the virus under control].We will only open up air bridges where it is safe to do so, and there will be more on that at the review period which is the  of June.Shapps also reaffirmed his backing for the -day travel quarantine rules, where people could be fined £, for breaking them.He also hinted that air bridges across the globe might not happen all at once.Meanwhile, Shapps and NHSs Powis reiterated that the R rate - for coronavirus rate of infection - remains below .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris no deal brexit talks
story: The Prime Minister is fighting to speed up the pace of Brexit negotiations as the head of the World Trade Organisation warned Britains recovery from COVID- could be hampered by no-deal. Mr Johnson will tell President of the European Council Charles Michel, President of the EU Commission Ursula von der Leyen and president of the European Parliament, David Sassoli, there needs to be a renewed energy and commitment in negotiations. But the PM is ready to threaten no-dealthere is no sign of progression in talks with the bloc, according to The Times.Last week Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove ruled out extending the transition period. But he agreed to a six-month delay before bringing in full border checks and collecting tarfs. The WTO has predicted that global trade could fall by a third because of the pandemic.WTO director-general Roberto Azevêdo warned the car industry and agriculture would be among the worst hit sectorsBritain didnt thrash out a deal with the bloc. The PM is expected to go to great s to protect jobs in the car industry in a speech to reboot the economy next month. One of the policies could offer Brits up to £, to trade in old diesel and petrols cars for electric cars in a bid to boost sales at companies such as Nissan who employ thousands at their Sunderland factory. But Mr Azevêdo said they would be subjected to heavy tarfsthe UK defaults to WTO trading rules under a no-deal Brexit. Mr Johnson wants a deal which gives Britain tarf-free access to EU markets but he has insisted the nation has nothing to fear by trading on WTO terms. The PM has stressed giving business certainty there will be no extension to the transition period with the EU - where the UK still has to follow the blocs rules - is more important. Mr Azevêdo told The Andrew Marr Show on BBC One WTO trade rules were not a catastrophe he said they “will impose a number of adjustments and those can be painful, particularly for some sectors”.He added: The less disruption the better, the less turbulence the better, and less turbulence is the closest to where you were before. Soyou can maintain the degree of integration and relationship that you had before Brexit, it is less traumatic thanyou have to go to WTO terms. The WTO boss thought there was a good chance the UK and EU would find a dealthere is political will to do so. He said: If people realise that a no-deal scenario is much less than optimal, Im pretty confident that negotiators could do this in a reasonable way with a reasonable time frame. A group of cross-party MPs are trying to get the Government to allow a vote on extending the transition period. title: black lives matter monkey gestures london
story: The vile scenes were filmed on Saturday in Trafalgar Square as groups of men tried to get to Black Lives Matter protesters throughout the day while police tried to block them.The video, which was shared on Twitter, shows a group of men standing above the steps before the entrance of the National Gallery gesturing at a crowd of Black Lives Matter protesters.One of the men in a red Coca-Cola shirt starts scratching his armpit - imitating the gestures of a monkey. Someone can be heard saying look at him - hes calling us monkeys before police are seen pulling the group of men away. The video has been seen more than , times as the person who shared it wrote: Today I saw how open and transparent racism is and the world is tolerating it... a man called me a monkey, threw glass bottles at man... while everyone that claims they bang for there block was at home sleeping... black people where’s the unity... stand together like the village.This weekend in London saw more than  people get arrested as statue-row protesters fought running battles with rival activists and charged at riot cops.Crowds of pro-statue campaigners earlier surrounded the monument of Winston Churchill, before peeling off to the Cenotaph - where they rushed up to the police blockade and pelted them with bottles and cans while chanting.  Ugly scenes throughout the afternoon showed the group, made up of war veterans, football fans and far-right organisations including Britain First, massing in a clear breach of social-distancing guidelines.Some were filmed attacking police officers in Westminster, with a group of yobs caught on camera aggressively targeting a group of peaceful Hyde Park picnickers and spitting at them.Police tried to keep this group and BLM protesters apart, after anti-racism activists first met for a peaceful gathering in Hyde Park.But as the day went on and the groups eventually came together at Trafalgar Square and Waterloo Station, there were a number of violent clashes between extreme elements.As the protests continued past the pm curfew, cops were seen standing guard outside the station in full riot gear - while flares and smoke bombs were thrown between groups and scraps broke out.BLM protesters were reportedly trying to get through police lines to take on the counter group - who had gathered earlier to defend London monuments before tussling with cops.A total  people were arrested on Saturday during demonstrations.One arrest included a -year-old man for urinating by the memorial of murdered PC Keith Palmer.A total of  officers were injured as protesters threw items at police or targeted them with violence.Commander Bas Javid on Sunday said: “The scenes officers encountered across central London yesterday were utterly shocking. Once again, they were pelted with missiles, or challenged by groups of men intent on violence.“Mindless hooliganism such as this is totally unacceptable and I am pleased arrests were made. We will now work closely with the courts in pursuit of justice.“I would like to thank those officers who showed enormous bravery in confronting violent behaviour, including our colleagues from British Transport Police and the City of London Police.”Prime Minister Boris Johnson tweeted over the weekend: Racist thuggery has no place on our streets. Anyone attacking the police will be met with full force of the law.These marches  protests have been subverted by violence and breach current guidelines.Racism has no part in the UK and we must work together to make that a reality.Multiple peaceful BLM protests were seen throughout London and the UK, with large groups gathering to stand and march in protest against racism.Protesters also defended memorials peacefully across the country.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hay fever worse coronavirus lockdown triggers pollen bomb
story: Fewer cars have been on the road due to restrictions that have been put in place due to the Covid- pandemic - meaning there is less pollution in the air.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesPiers Morgan said that one of the down sides of cleaner air and a lack of pollution is that a pollen barrier has been removed which would usually be in place.He said: All the respiratory experts are saying that people are getting a lot bigger void of pollen than they usually would through the clean air and its causing bad hay fever.Good Morning Britain’s Dr Hilary Jones confirmed this and said a pollen bomb could be caused by more of it falling down, whereas it would usually be blocked by pollution.Speaking on the show this morning he said: When you have less particulate matter in the atmosphere and it brings it down to earth you have less circulating antigens getting into your eyes and your nose.Absolutely its a downside.He also joked with Piers that he had been taking dodgy French pills to cure his hay fever.It comes after Piers admitted that his coronavirus scare was down to the worst hay fever he has ever had.Dr Hilary had previously said that a decrease in road traffic was helping to contribute to pollution levels.Speaking on the show in May he said: What we know is it’s been one of the driest Mays on record, so the pollen count is really high.“And we also know that diesel particles particularly, pollution in other words, can combine with pollen in the atmosphere and drag it downwards.Today is set to be challenging for many people who suffer from hay fever as the pollen count is at “very high” levels across most of the country.London and the South East, South West, East, the East and West Midlands, Wales, North West England, Yorkshire and the Humber and Northern Ireland all have very high pollen counts today.This is while the North East has high levels.Dumfries, Galloway, Lothian and borders have medium, as does title: china coronavirus cases second wave europe opens
story: Officials in the Chinese capital reported  locally transmitted cases in the past four days, following  days with zero cases.The outbreak - linked to the citys biggest fresh meat, fish and vegetable market - emerged just as European nations were opening their borders to tourists for the first time in months.There were  new cases in Beijing yesterday, following  on Saturday, six on Friday and one on Thursday.Tens of thousands of residents have been told to go for testing at a sports stadium in an effort to halt the spread.The new outbreak has been traced to the sprawling Xinfadi market, a giant complex of warehouses and trading spaces the size of  football pitches.At least three districts in western Beijing entered war-time mode with round-the-clock security checkpoints, schools closed and temperature checks reinstated at shops and offices.The risk of the epidemic spreading is very high, so we should take resolute and decisive measures, Xu Hejiang, spokesman for the Beijing city government, told a news conference.Some districts sent officials to residential buildings in a knock, knock operation to identy people who had visited Xinfadi or been in contact with people who had.Reports claimed coronavirus was found on chopping boards used to slice imported salmon - prompting supermarkets to pull products from shelves.The general manager on Xinfadi was dismissed as police shut the market down over the weekend and tested workers.One vegetable wholesaler told Reuters he has been quarantined for  days at a hotel even though his test was negative.Xinfadi is more than  times larger than the Wuhan wet market where the global Covid- pandemic is thought to have originated.Other new cases have been found in Liaoning, Hebei and Sichuan provinces - all confirmed or suspected to be linked to the outbreak in Beijing.Authorities in other regions were told to warn residents against travel to Beijing and to monitor those who had just come back.Health chiefs are investigatingthe virus came in from overseas after China claimed it had virtually eradicated the disease with tough lockdown measures.One government epidemiologist said DNA sequencing of the virus showed the Xinfadi outbreak could have come from Europe.The World Health Organization said it was informed of the outbreak it understands that genetic sequences will be released as soon as possible once further laboratory analyses are completed.Meanwhile a number of European countries continued to lt the painful lockdown measures imposed in March.Greece is now allowing travellers from nations deemed low-risk, and today it opened its borders to all EU residents.Germany, Belgium, France and Austria are following suit tomorrowAnd Spain said it will reopen its borders to tourists on June , ten days ahead of schedule - although Brits are banned until at least July .But there have been two new outbreaks in Rome, with  cases and five deaths at a hospital and  infections at a building inhabited by squatters.It means the virus hasnt lost its infectiousness, it isnt weakening. We shouldnt let down our guard, said WHO deputy director Ranieri Guerra.Egypt is also set to welcome back tourists to beach resorts in July, and Perus Machu Picchu is to reopen next month with reduced visitor numbers.This week the English Premier League makes its long-awaitedwith games played in empty stadiums after an enforced three month hiatus.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: commuters wear masks compulsory public transport coronavirus
story: Brits pulled on the face coverings as they got on trains and Tubes this morning to stop the spread of the deadly bug.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesCommuters were this morning pictured at Waterloo station wearing masks as they headed back to work.British Transport Police will have the power to fine rule breakers £they fail to wear the safety precautions.And BTP today tweeted out a reminder to Brits to make sure they wear the masks - with the items being handed out at many stations to make sure people are following the rules.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps announced that from June  it will be mandatory for people to wear face coverings on public transport.This includes on trains, buses, trams, ferries and aircraft.Masking the mouth and nose reduces the risk of asymptomatic carriers — people who are infected but showing no symptoms — from passing on the bug.A DIY face-covering can be used — even just a scarf or a thin cloth mask.Railway staff will also adopt the mask-wearing guidelines.But the Government has warned that for face coverings to be effective, people must wash their hands before putting them on and taking them off.The government is asking people to use a simple face covering, and not buy up PPE standard medical masks as they still are needed for the NHS.Private hire taxis and minicabs are also included in the ­measures, but the rules do not cover bus stops, railway stations and other terminals.Anyone not wearing a mask will be kicked off unless they are disabled, young children or have breathing dficulties.Face coverings are now also compulsory in hospitals, with staff, visitors and outpatients required to wear them.Mr Shapps said that it would be an England-only rule, but he expects that Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will follow suit.He said: You can be refused travelyou dont comply and you could be fined.The Department of Health said previously, after considering the latest scientic advice from SAGE, that face coverings can help reduce the spread of Covid-.They stressed that the evidence shows face coverings can stop you passing coronavirus on to others,you are asymptomatic or have yet to develop symptoms.A new German study last week showed that the compulsory use of facemasks slows the spread of coronavirus by  per cent.The study was able to use the staggered introduction of masks in shops and on public transport across Germany as a natural experiment to test how effective the masks were.Looking at the new cases in the days that followed the experiment, scientists found that there is “strong and convincing statistical support” that the masks “strongly reduced the number of incidences”. Scientists have even suggested that wearing face masks might protect against coronavirus better than handwashing or social distancing.But some scientists criticised the mandatory use of face masks on the grounds that there was still no evidence that masks helped stop the spread of the virus.Other groups argue that without strong evidence, there was a clear plausible mechanism for how even homemade cloth masks could stop onward transmission You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailNon-essential shops and zoos reopen from Monday  June in England as the economy slowly creaks back into le. For the first time in three months youaposll be able to go clothes shopping and see the lemurs. But there will be strict social distancing rules in place and firms will be ordered to carry out more hygiene measures than usual. Expect queues outside shops and high demand for tickets for attractions allowed to reopen. Meanwhile, people who live alone or single parents are allowed to form a bubble with one other household in England. This means breaking the two-metre rule for the first time to hug and kiss, share childcare, stay the night and have sexthataposs your thing. Hereaposs everything you need to know about the lockdown changes this week. Two separate households in England can now join together in a “support bubble” under certain conditions. They won’t need to follow the two-metre rule - meaning they can hug, kiss, share childcare and meals, hang out indoors, stay the night and even have sex for the first time since March . One of the two households in each bubble must be a “single-adult household”. This means either a person who lives alone, or a single parent who lives with children under . There’s an incredible £million of funding from The National Lottery being shared among good causes around the UK – and it’s all thanks to you. Le’s been harder than ever for young carers in lockdown. But charities like TEN North East are offering vital support thanks to National Lottery funding. Program lead Levi Cosker  says: One mother calls our project a leline – without us she wouldn’t have any support. Click here to read her amazing full story. Visit national-lottery news to learn more about how you’re helping. The other household they are joining with can be of any size, and can have more than one adult in it. However, in total each bubble must only consist of two households - and each household must keep the arrangement “exclusive”. That means a person living alone cannot form multiple bubbles with multiple households. Likewise, a family cannot form multiple bubbles with more than one lonely relative. For a full explanation and QA click here. What changes in England from June  Non-essential shops reopen  Non-essential shops will be allowed to reopen for the first time for almost three months in England. Stories will need strict social distancing measures, much like those weaposve already seen in supermarkets and other essential stores. Brands vowing to reopen bang on time from June  include Primark, GAME, Debenhams, O, EE and BT, HM, Lush, GAME, H Samuel and Argos. John Lewis is set to open most stores from June , while Next will open a handful followed by others in the coming weeks. Types of shop allowed to reopen include:Fashion shops Charity shops Betting shops and arcades Tailors, dress fitters and fashion designers Auction houses Antique stores Retail art galleries Photography studios Gt shops and retail spaces in theatres, museums, libraries, heritage sites and tourism sites Mobile phone stores Craft fairsFace coverings will be mandatory on public transport  Everyone travelling on public transport in England will be required to wear a face covering from June . Wearing a face covering - not a surgical mask - will be part of the conditions of carriage for travelling on public transport. That means travellers could be refused permission to board buses or trainsthey refuse to comply with the order. Serious offenders could be fined, but ministers have claimed people will largely comply and this wonapost be needed.  Hospital visitors and staff will need to wear face coverings and masks All hospital visitors and outpatients in England will be required to wear face coverings - while all hospital staff will be required to wear higher-grade, type  or  surgical masks. Zoos, safari parks and drive-in cinemasstart to re-open  Zoos, safari parks and drive-in cinemas are set to reopen in England from Monday. Boris Johnson has said they can reopen as long as they follow social distancing rules. That means their on-site cafes and restaurants are expected to operate as take-away only. Only outdoor attractions are allowed to reopen, so reptile houses and indoor aquariums will remain closed. Sites will be operating at reduced capacity, and there may be one-way systems in place. And of course, because very few things are likely to be open it will be busy, you should book your ticket online in advance to ensure youaposre not disappointed when you turn up. Churches reopen but only for private prayer  Places of worship reopen in England from June , but only for private prayer and not for services. Iniduals are expected to be able to reflect and pray while adhering to social-distancing rules - but worship groups, weddings and other services will still not be permitted. In line with government guidance churches will be expected to be deep-cleaned regularly and should remove shared books from public areas. Churches have been closed since  March, following instructions from the Government. School pupils in Years  and a quarter at a time  Secondary schools in England can reopen for Years  and  from June , but not all students will be allowed toat the same time. Only a quarter of eligible pupils will be allowed in school at any one time - meaning schools have had to instigate special timetables and classes to make the system work. Secondary schools are not likely to fully reopen until September at the earliest. Students who dowill be encouraged to travel separately and avoid public transport. The teaching of vulnerable children and those of critical workers in all year groups will continue until the start of the summer holidays. Some primary schools will open a bit further than they are now While around half of the UKaposs primary schools have been open to more pupils from June , some have remained closed to all but key workersapos kids. This meant nursery, reception, year one and year six pupils in some parts of the country havenapost yet got back into the classroom. Some places, like Doncaster and Liverpool, stopped schools reopening on June , but will see them reopening their doors on Monday. Donapost expect more big changes to primary school attendance before September though. Plans for all pupils in Years , ,  and  tofor a month before the summer break in England have been dropped by Education Secretary Gavin Williamson. Instead schools are just being asked to bring back whoever they can, depending on capacity. He told MPs he is now aiming to get all children back to school in September,possible. What has already changed in recent weeks in EnglandJune : Primary schools were asked to reopen to years R,  and  in England - though only about half of them actually did June : People allowed to meet in socially-distanced groups of up to  outdoors, including in private gardens June : Car showrooms and outdoor markets allowed to reopen June : Dentists begin to reopen with extra hygiene measures in place June : -day quarantine comes into forced for those arriving in the UK June : Some parking charges that were suspended . What weaposll still need to wait until July for - or longer Pubs, restaurants and bars Pubs, restaurants, bars and cafes are not expected to reopen in England until July  at the earliest. They can already operate as takeaways - good news for pubs next to parks or beaches - but they canapost have people drinking on the premises, even in the beer garden. Pubs arenapost guaranteed to reopen on July  - thataposs just the starting date for the hospitality and leisure industry so boozers might come later. When they do open itaposll have to be with social distancing rules in place. Hairdressers and nail bars  Hairdressers, barbers and beauty salons are also only opening from July  at the earliest. And like pubs, the date could end up being later because itaposs hard to avoid being in close contact with someone cutting your hair. The two-metre rule Boris Johnson is under pressure to drop the two-metre social distancing rule down to one metre or one and a half. This would increase the risk of catching the virus from someone but allow the economy to restart. The government has made clear that the two-metre rule is still in all its guidance, including draft rules for pubs and cafes to reopen. But that could change in future. Boris Johnson has said he wants to cut the distance but only when itaposs supported by the science. In basic terms, that means waiting until your overall risk from catching the virus in wider society is so low, some extra risk from the person youaposre next to is acceptable. Scientists say youaposre  to  times more at risk from one metre away than two metres away. Wider school reopenings

Married couples or those in civil partnerships  who have reported they are suffering from aposhighapos levels of anxiety more than doubled in the first month of Britainaposs shutdown.Pensioners aged over  were also twice as likely to be highly stressed as those aged -, the ONS found, with part of the blame being attributed to reporting of their higher risk of serious illness and death from coronavirus, and also their higher levels of loneliness.Both of these groups, married couples and pensioners, reported the lowest anxiety levels pre-pandemic.The figures come after the rules were relaced allowing  apossupport bubblesapos containing two households, to help those living alone. Those who are married or in a civil partnership are more likely to be balancing homeschooling alongside other commitments.A quarter of them are homeschooling during the pandemic, compared with approximately  in  people who are single, separated or orced.Between  April and  May  a higher percentage of those who are married or in a civil partnership also said that homeschooling was negatively affecting their well-beingwhen compared with all other marital status groups .Around one in five of those who reported high levels of anxiety during lockdown said that their work had been affected because they were finding working from home dficult, the ONS said. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum whose son has been left with PTSD after his dadaposs traumatic death, has warned others not to put their family in the same position. Kirsty Walshaposs husband Shane drowned after falling over a small wall in Shrewsbury, on his way home from a night out with friends. Shane was propelled forward into the River Severn, where he went into cold water shock. Dad-of-two Shane was unable to shout for help, or move his arms and legs to save himself and he drowned alone, on September , . His we Kirsty went through three days of hell after reporting -year-old Shane missing when he didnapost come home. For the latest on the coronavirus pandemic, click here   She had been shown CCTV by police of Shane tripping and falling into the river, a moment she says she replays in her mind over and over again. Kirsty was at the riverside on September , when volunteers from West Mercia Search and Rescue found Shane under the water. Shane, who lit up a room when he walked in left behind daughter Adalynn, who was  days away from her first birthday, and three-year-old son Corey.  Now almost three years on, little Corey, aged six, battles daily with his mental health following the trauma of his dadaposs death. Mum Kirsty told : Corey remembers everything, he has had a traumatic experience that nobody should. Itaposs had a huge impact on his day to day le and this is something that we have to go through every day. Corey was diagnosed with post traumatic stress disorder and has been having counselling and therapy, but finds celebrations and happy events among his hardest to deal with. Kirsty said Corey asks why Shane canapost come down from heaven and hold his hand when heaposs had a sad day, or why he didnapost come to his birthday to blow out the candles on his cake.  The -year-old mum said: What am I supposed to say to a six-year-old  The impact on his mental health is enormous. He went through an awful trauma at a young age and he will have to deal with that his whole le. Itaposs devastating that I canapost take this away from him. When he is having night terrors or screaming for his dad, I canapost take that pain away.  Following Shaneaposs death Kirsty has become an advocate with West Mercia Search and Rescue, who she thanks for bringing her husband back to his family so they could say goodbye. She has set up a free online water course which is suitable for people of all ages and teaches you what to doyou get into trouble, or see someone in the water. Kirsty also gives talks on water safety and is determined not to let another family go through what hers still does, every day.  She said: Shane went into cold water shock, itaposs a strong power that stops you being able to shout for help. You canapost move your arms and legs to be able to swim and your heart rate rises. Shane was intoxicated, so everything would have been heightened too. Every year  men drown after a night out in the UK, and  more people drown while fishing.Another  also drown while out on a walk or run, and the majority had no intention of going into the water. Kirsty added: Even though it is warm at the moment, the water is still so cold. When cold water shock happens, you arenapost going to make it out. It takes over your body.
