England today after  weeks of being shut as some lockdown measures ease.Major names opening some of their stores include Apple, Argos, Curryaposs, PC World, HM, House of Fraser and Lush. Photographs outside reopened Primark stores showed huge queues of eager shoppers - one seen donning a full bodysuit of personal protective equipment. The Prime Minister announced on Monday  May that all non-essential retailers in England will be allowed to open with social distancing in place from  June. Any business reopening must demonstrate that it is compliant to customers and businesses who fail to comply by the rules will face harsh penalties. Zoos will also be allowed to open in the changes seen in England today.Meanwhile, people who live alone or single parents are allowed to form a bubble with one other household in England. For more of the latest updates throughout today, follow our LIVE blog, below to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at  mirror email  -after the press conference every evening. Key EventsWoman spotted in full bodysuit of PPE as queues force Primark to reopen early:Face coverings must be worn on public transport from today::Homeschooling leads to lockdown anxiety surge in married couplesLockdown has seen a surge in anxiety across the UK with married couples the worst affected - largely because of the extra stress of home schooling.Married couples or those in civil partnerships who have reported they are suffering from #xhigh#x levels of anxiety more than doubled in the first month of Britain#xs shutdown.Pensioners aged over  were also twice as likely to be highly stressed as those aged -, the ONS found, with part of the blame being attributed to reporting of their higher risk of serious illness and death from coronavirus, and also their higher levels of loneliness. Both of these groups, married couples and pensioners, reported the lowest anxiety levels pre-pandemic.Click here for the full story. :Shoppers at reopened department store given guard of honour by applauding staffShoppers at a major city department store received a guard of honour from applauding staff as the store reopened today.Video footage showed a countdown #x--#x before the first customer in line walked through the doors of Fenwick in Newcastle.Customers can be seen wearing masks in the video while staff wear visors over their faces.Some have also opted for gloves.As the customers enter, keeping a distance between each other, the staff members break out into a round of applause for them.Shoppers use hand sanitiser from a dispenser right at the entrance of the store.It comes as many non-essential shops all around England have begun to open their doors today.Our full story is here. :Quarter of secondary pupils sitting exams next year allowed in school from todayJust a quarter of Year  and  pupils will be allowed on site at one time as secondary schools reopen today.The students are all set to sit their GCSEs and A-level next summer but due to social distancing rules the size of classes have shrunk dramatically.The Government wants pupils to have #xface-to-face#x support before they sit their exams but the amount contact time available will y from school to school.While some are offering #xweekly contact sessions#x for pupils or prioritising contact for those who have #xstruggled#x with remote learning an estimated one in eight schools will remain closed.Click here for our story in full. :Inside Primark as stores reopen - what its really like under the new rulesWith no online store, Primark fans have been unable to get hold of their fast fashion fix for months - that ended today.Shoppers woke up at :am to queue outside branches, with stores opening their doors early to try and ease congestion.But once inside, things weren#xt quite the way they used to be.Mum Terri Hughes, , from Tamworth, said: #xCI#xve just come into Birmingham as its the best place around here for shopping and their Primark is great.#xCIt was all very British and orderly in there. You can see a bit of a scramble for clothes usually in Primark, but that wasn#xt the case today.#xCIt#xs still a bit eerie in a way, seeing everyone in face masks - but at least you can tell we#xre over the worst of it. We just need the pubs to reopen now.#xDClick here to see the full story. Blue bubbles have been added at the tills:All the things you can do in England from todayNon-essential shops and zoos reopen from Monday  June in England as the economy slowly creaks back into le.For the first time in three months you#xll be able to go clothes shopping and see the lemurs.But there will be strict social distancing rules in place and firms will be ordered to carry out more hygiene measures than usual.Expect queues outside shops and high demand for tickets for attractions allowed to reopen.Meanwhile, people who live alone or single parents are allowed to form a #xCbubble#xD with one other household in England.This means breaking the two-metre rule for the first time to hug and kiss, share childcare, stay the night and have sexthat#xs your thing.Click here for everything you need to know about the lockdown changes this week.Commuters about to board the train at Hunts Cross train station in Liverpool :Customer shopping for trainers says it feels like ato some kind of normalityMasks are now mandatory on public transport but are not compulsory in shops, although customers queuing for the Apple store on Regent Street in central London were told they must wear face coverings once inside. Shoppers were told to use hand sanitiser as they walked into Primark in Oxford Street, and some customers wore gloves as they browsed the rails. Dispensers have been stationed at the shop#xs entrance, where members of staff are observing customers as they enter. A queue of people also waited outside Nike Town on Oxford Street shortly after am, ahead of the store#xs opening at am. Ricky Young, who turned out to buy trainers, said it felt like ato some kind of normality. Askedhe expected it to be busy, the -year-old plasterer told the PA news agency: #xCNo, I actually thought people might have been sleeping or didn#xt want to go out. #xCBut the doors are open again, it#xs back to almost normal, back to business - but we just have to line up.#xDA queue outside Nike in Oxford Circus :Worldwide coronavirus cases cross . millionMore than . million people have been reported to be infected by coronavirus globally and , have died, according to a Reuters tally. Infections have been reported in more than  countries and territories since the first cases were identied in China in December .:Up to % of shielding people have left home against adviceUp to half of people who are shielding from Covid- have left their home against advice, while a third have seen their mental health worsen, according to new data.Figures from the Office for National Statistics , based on a survey of , people who are shielding, found that % have been out since shielding began, while % have stayed at home.People who are shielding were initially told not to leave their home or garden, including for exercise, shopping or to go to work.But on June , the rules in England were relaxed to say people could leave their homes once a day for exercise. The British government further relaxed Covid- quarantine measures in England:Today is clearly an important milestone in ing the country to normalityOliver Rowe, director of reputation research at YouGov, said: #xCToday is clearly an important milestone in ing the country to normality, however there is a lot of work to be done yet to convince shoppers that it#xs business as usual. #xCHalf of Brits say that they#xre uncomfortable ing to pubs, restaurants and clothing shops, and large portions of the public are unsure they could adequately socially distance once inside. #xCWhen split by gender, the concern is highest amongst women, who said they were more uncomfortable than men, sometimes by large margins, about ing to all outlets put to them by YouGov. #xCThere#xs clearly more for business and the Government to dothey#xre going to entice shoppers back to the high street but it#xs tough to see how they do that while the dual health and economic uncertainty remains in people#xs minds.#xDHuge queues outside the Nike store in Oxford Circus, London :Less than half of Brits feel comfortable ing to clothes shops, survey showsLess than half of Britons feel comfortable ing to clothes shops, according to a survey. Results of YouGov polling carried out earlier this month suggested just % of people were comfortable to go back into such stores and only % think they would be able to stay the required two metres away from other shoppers. Forty-one per cent of people said they believe it is the right time for the shops to reopen but % said it was too soon. One keen shopper carrying large bags :KEY EVENTWoman spotted in full bodysuit of PPE as queues force Primark to reopen earlyA shopper donned a full bodysuit of personal protective equipment before heading out to Primark this morning as the store reopened for the first time since March.The woman, dressed head-to-toe in a white suit similar to the sort of thing you usually only see from forensics officers in crime dramas, was also wearing blue disposable gloves and a face mask.But she wasn#xt the only person going to extraordinary s to get her Primark fix - with people getting up hours early to be first in line.See the full story here. This shopper wears PPE:Long queues outside London Zoo ahead of parks reopeningLong queues of people formed outside ZSL London Zoo in Regent#xs Park, west London, ahead of the park#xs reopening. Parents and children were asked to respect two-metre social distancing and many wore face coverings. Jamie Turner, site manager for ZSL London Zoo, said just under , tickets had been sold for Monday and that theof so many customers was #xCbeautul to see#xD. People queue to enter London Zoo :Spain reopens borders for , Germans in tourism pilot projectSpain reopened to a select group of German tourists on Monday in a pilot project which will bring , holidaymakers to the Balearic Islands to find out how mass tourism can work in a time of coronavirus. Dozens of mask-wearing sunseekers queued at Duesseldorf airport on Monday morning to board tour operator TUI#xs flight to Palma de Mallorca, eager to test arrangements for socially distanced holidaymaking two weeks before Spain fully reopens. Hotels are limited to running at % occupancy and will have infra-red cameras at their entrances to measure guests#x body temperatures. :Shoppers told to use hand sanitisers with dispensers at entrancesShoppers were told to use hand sanitiser as they walked into Primark in London#xs Oxford Street, which opened its doors at am. Dispensers have been stationed at the shop#xs entrance, where members of staff are observing customers as they enter. A sign on the window of the store, near Tottenham Court Road, advises shoppers about the steps taken to ensure #xCthe wellbeing of our colleagues and customers#xD. Some wore face coverings as they browsed the rails, while others also opted for gloves.A shopper appears to be dressed in a Hazmat suit :First easyJet flight departs Liverpool John Lennon Airport in  weeksEasyJet#xs first flight from Liverpool John Lennon Airport has departed after an -week hiatus.The flight to Belfast left Liverpool at .am and is scheduled to arrive at .am.EasyJet told the Liverpool Echo the cabin is thoroughly disinfected daily providing surface protection from viruses for at least  hours.:Primarks Covid-ready safety measuresLiverpool Echo reporter Elle May Rice, who was down at the city centre Primark store for the reopening, said: #xCThere are barriers as you come in as well so it#xs one way in, one way out. #xCStock is much more spaced out than usual too.#xDThe safety measures Primark has taken include:Extra security - Extra security staff will be added to the team to help with a queuing system and to make sure people are following the rules.Warning signs - Signs will be put around the shops and on the floor to explain the rules.Emptier aisles - The number of customers allowed in the store at any time will be limited. By having fewer people in the store, both shoppers and staff will be able to stay a safe distance away from each other.Tills closed - Primark will only reopen every other till, meaning there is extra staff being staff working behind the counter and customers paying.PPE - All staff will be available to every member of staff who wants to wear one.Sanitiser - There will also be hand sanitiser stations at the front of every store, so customers can wash their hands as they arrive.Screens - Perspex screens have been put in front of the tills.More cleaners - All shops will be cleaned more often during the day, with particular focus on #xtouch points#x - including tills, escalators and lts. They will also do extra cleaning of staff areas.Primark in Liverpool City centre :Homeless cancer survivor, , forced to live on sons driveway for two yearsA homeless elderly couple are begging for a home after spending two years living in a cramped campervan on their son#xs driveway.The Birmingham couple have told how they have been forced to live in the situation for two years.Philip Higgs, , and we Pamela, , are now appealing to Birmingham City Council to help them find proper accommodation after enduring the coronavirus lockdown in the van.Click here to read their story.The couple have lived in the campervan for two years :Reducing social distancing to m would result in increase in riskDr Michael Tildesley, infectious disease scientist at the University of Warwick, said reducing the social distancing restriction from two metres to one #xCwill result in an increase in risk#xD. The Government#xs two-metre rule is currently under review, as ministers balance public health priorities with enabling more businesses to reopen. Speaking on BBC Breakfast on Monday, Dr Tildesley said: #xCThe evidence is still slightly unclear - depending upon the studies it could be anything from about twice the risk to  times the risk. #xCSo there is an increase in risk with going down to one metre. #xCBut I have to stress this is purely based upon public health, and the Government has to consider economic factors before taking a decision.#xD:Shoppers trying to look through Primark windows to see which products in stockIn Wolverhampton, shoppers tweeted crowds of more than  by am this morning, while in Liverpool, crowds are already being allowed inside.In Hull, it#xs similar scenes, though the city centre store won#xt be allowing crowds inside until am.#xCMany shoppers are trying to look through the windows to see which products are in stock at Primark,#xD one shopper tweeted.:Huge queues already seen outside PrimarkHuge queues are already gathering outside Primark stores across England as the chain prepares to reopen for the first time since March .Crowds of shoppers have been pictured outside the chain#xs Birmingham flagship branch - which will today welcome shoppers for the first time in three months, following a lockdown that has cost the business #xA.billion.A total of  stores will reopen to the public - with two metre social distancing and one-way queues in place.Other measures include extra security staff, safety signs and revised hours as the chain slowly reopens for business.However, in line with Government guidelines, staff and customers will not be required to wear PPE or face coverings inside stores.On entry, there will be blue bubbles all floors, reminding people to stay two metres apart as they are wait in line.Every branch will also have a separate entrance and exit, with marshals on hand to keep count of how many customers come in and out.Basket handles will be cleaned after every use and customers will be asked to use a contactless hand sanitising unit.Click here for the full story. Queues of shoppers waiting for the opening of Primarks Flagship store in Birmingham :Volunteers hand out masks to commuters in LondonVolunteers handed out blue masks to commuters as they entered and left Vauxhall Underground station in London, where two security guards were stationed to stop people taking more masks than necessary. A team of five volunteers were in place in the ticket hall from .am. The majority of those travelling wore a face covering while a handful picked up a free mask, which were laid out on two tables. Two British Transport Police officers stood near the ticket gates monitoring those travelling up on the escalators.Commuters at Victoria Station in London :Some of the shops reopening todaySome of the non-essential shops set to reopen today include Currys PC World which will open  stores.Debenhams will reopen  of their stores in England. HM is planning to open #xCthe majority#xD of its stores in England on Monday, although it wouldn#xt confirm exact numbers and fitting rooms will stay closed.:Commuters head to work with face coveringsCommuters have been pictured heading to work wearing face coverings. As of today, people must wear face coverings on public transport in England.Below is a photo of commuters at Waterloo Station in London on the first morning since the new rules came in. Commuters at Waterloo station, London :Strictly pros to isolate together for two weeks so they can shoot group dancesStrictly Come Dancing professionals are reportedly planning to isolate together so that they can film group dances together.The show#xs producers are looking at ways of ensuring the BBC has a Strictly series this year despite the coronavirus pandemic leading to social distancing and other restrictions.So that the show goes on, The Sun has reported that isolating the pro dancers in a hotel for two weeks would mean that group dances could be filmed and used throughout the series.Click here for the story in full. :EastEnders filming begins again with stars social distancing in scenesWalford is coming to le again as the cameras start rolling on the EastEnders set after its enforced shutdown due to the coronavirus lockdown.In the first pics of the new scenes being filmed, Danny Dyer can be seen social distancing from Kellie Bright as they show how le in Albert Square will change.Danny, as Mick Carter, and Kellie as his on-screen we Linda Carter can be seen outside the Queen Vic pub with the coronavirus protocols in place.Cast and crew have ed to Elstree Studios in Borehamwood, Hertfordshire for the first episodes since the lockdown, with the hope that the BBC soap will be back on TV by September, though this has not been confirmed yet by the Beeb.Click here for the story. Kellie Bright and Danny Dyer social distancing in new EastEnders scenes :Coronavirus resurgence in Beijing promptsof tough measuresBeijing reported its second consecutive day of record new numbers of COVID- cases on Monday, adding urgency to efforts to rein in a sudden resurgence of the coronavirus in the Chinese capital.The recent outbreak has been traced to a major wholesale food market, Xinfadi, which accounts for % of Beijing#xs farm produce supply sourced both domestically and from overseas. The market has been shut, tens of thousands of nearby residents are being tested for the virus and a city-wide campaign launched to identy people who have recently visited the market or have been in contact with people who have.:Hong Kongs Disneyland to reopen on June Hong Kong#xs Disneyland theme park said on Monday it will reopen on June  to a reduced number of visitors and with enhanced health measures after the coronavirus outbreak forced it to close in late January. The city has reported only a handful of new cases recently, with its total so far standing at , infections and four deaths. The majority of the park#xs shopping and dining locations will restart operations with #xCcontrolled capacity,#xD while social distancing measures will be implemented in queues, restaurants and other facilities. Hotel services will also resume gradually. Disinfection will be carried out more frequently and hand sanitisers will be made available for visitors, who will be required to go through temperature screening, wear a face mask and sign a health declaration.:Germanys confirmed coronavirus cases rise by  to ,The number of confirmed coronavirus cases in Germany increased by  to ,, data from the Robert Koch Institutefor infectious diseases showed on Monday. The reported death toll rose by four to ,, the tally showed.:Thailand reports no new coronavirus cases and no new deathsThailand has reported no new coronavirus infections or deaths today. It has had a total of , confirmed cases and  fatalities. It is the second time in five days that no cases were reported and marked  days without a local transmission. There are , patients who have recovered. All recent cases have been found in quarantine among Thais ing from abroad, said Taweesin Wisanuyothin, a spokesman for the government#xs COVID- task force.:KEY EVENTFace coverings must be worn on public transport from todayBrits could be fined up to #xAthey are don#xt wear a face mask on public transport from today.The Government has made it law to wear them on all trains, buses, trams, ferries and aircraft in a bid to reduce the spread of coronavirus.Covering the mouth and nose like this cuts the risk of asymptomatic carriers - people who are infected but showing no symptoms - from passing on the virus.DIY face coverings can be used, even scarves or thin cloth masks.Railway staff will also have to follow the new rule.British Transport Police can fine those not wearing masks #xA on the spot.A commuter wearing a face covering at Victoria Station in London this morning More OnCoronavirus

The Queen, who was dressed in a floral silk jade grey and dusty pink dress by Stewart Parvin and hat by Rachel Trevor-Morgan, with the diamond leek brooch of the Welsh Guard, sat alone on a seat on a dais, a raised  decorated with pink begonias and bay trees to watch. The parade included  socially distanced soldiers from the st Battalion Welsh Guards - including the first ever female guardsman to parade for the Queen’s birthday. Her Majesty looked on with pride at the assembled military outfit, accompanied by Vice-Admiral Tony Johnstone-Burt, Master of the Household, Lt Col Michael Vernon, Comptroller and Major Nana Twemasi-Ankrah, the Queen’s equerry. The Queen, , was greeted by a royal salute before watching military drills by the guardsmen who are used to standing shoulder-to-shoulder, but had specially adapted their manoeuvres to keep . metres apart, under the watchful eye of Lieutenant Colonel Henry Llewelyn-Usher, who commanded the ceremony.

title: pooch looks like completely different
story: NewsPooch looks like completely dferent dog after shedding half his body weightAlicia Taylor and Liam Applegarth, from Watton, Norfolk, were terried when Cocker Spaniel, Bailey, started vomiting blood and rushed him to the vet where he was diagnosed with pancreatitis - a painful inflammation of the organ that can be caused by obesityShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle EditorJamie Blue Mountain:,  JUN NewsEven the vet couldnt believe how much weight Bailey, pictured with owner Liam, had lost on the new diet " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAlicia Taylor, , always wanted the best for her gorgeous Cocker Spaniel, Bailey, taking him for long walks and making sure he ate the correct portions. So she was horried when she found her beloved pooch vomiting blood and rushed him to the vet for tests. Four-year-old Bailey was diagnosed with pancreatitis, a painful inflammation of the organ that can be caused by obesity, and was put on anti-inflammatory medication for two weeks and a diet overhaul was recommended. Alicia, from Watton, Norfolk, said: When youaposre a dog owner you think youaposre doing the very best for your dog. So we really took it to heart when we found out we had contributed to his illness. We felt like weaposd let ourselves down - heaposs our everything. Alicia, , and her boyfriend, Liam Applegarth, , who is in the armed forces, admitted they didnapost know too much about dog nutrition so just bought a bag of food from the supermarket which claimed to be perfect for an all round diet But after his health scare, theyaposve swapped him to a raw food diet and the dference is incredible. She said: I just couldnapost believe how quickly he took to it. It grossed me out at first, the idea of using raw meat, but when you think about it dogs werenapost made to eat kibble.  In the wild theyaposd be eating food theyaposd caught. Between starting his new diet August  and the summer of , Bailey shed half his body weight, slimming down from kg to kg - drawing admiring comments from fellow dog walkers who had known him since he was a puppy. Friends, family and fellow dog walkers were lost for words,said Alicia, who is also delighted to report that he has never suffered with pancreatitis again. The vet was absolutely shocked. He couldnapost believe it, I donapost think he could believe that such dference was made by swapping to raw food  - and heaposs a vet!  And when I started looking at old photos, I realised why everyone was making such a fuss - he really was a super slimming pooch. Alicia and Liam had wanted a dog since they first moved in together, in June , but it had been impossible as they were living in rented accommodation. So, after buying their own place in , getting a puppy had been their priority and they had settled on a Cocker Spaniel, as they thought the breed would suit their personalities and lestyle. Alicia said:  We wanted an active, lively dog to fit in with our lestyle, as weaposre a young couple and quite active - so a Cocker Spaniel ticked all the boxes.  Theyaposre known for their kooky personalities, after all. Falling head over heels for Bailey, who they bought from a local breeder, he made their little family feel complete. Alicia said: He was everything we could have hoped for in a first pet. He was your perfect puppy, so friendly and engaging. He was so happy to see anybody. Wanting to be responsible, they had decided to have him neutered - heeding the warnings that his metabolism might slow, causing him to gain a few kilos, by exercising portion control. Alicia said: We gave him strict portions of a generic, supermarket-bought kibble, as well as daily short walks and a three-hour walk once a week.  So the couple were flummoxed by what was causing his considerable weight gain  - only realising once Alicia started researching alternative diets on the web that it was probably the kind of food they had been giving him. Looking back, we know now it was the kibble that was the weight gain culprit, but we didnapost know anything about nutrition for dogs back then. We just chose the most colourful brand, which made the best claims about dog health. He went from being an energetic, fun-loving dog to a lethargic and lazy hound. Recalling the upsetting day they realised how poorly Bailey was, she said: I woke up one morning and could hear Bailey retching at the bottom of the bed.  Liam was away with the forces at the time. I got up to let Bailey out and he ran into the garden and would not stop throwing up. At first I thought it was just an upset stomach. He didnapost eat anything that day, and the next he was vomiting up blood - it was terrying.  They rushed him to the vet where he was put on a drip for  hours and given a full health screening - including an ultrasound and blood tests. She started researching alternative diets and came across Natureaposs Menu - and hasnapost looked back. She said: He looks like a completely dferent dog.

A survey of more than , workers at state secondary schools by app provider, Teacher Tapp, found that  per cent will resume lessons for students beyond key worker children next week. Some schools and colleges are ‘prioritising more contact for pupils who have struggled with remote learning’, ‘providing review sessions’ for all or ‘building the frequency of contact sessions over time’. At Heathfield Community College in East Sussex, around  per cent of year  pupils will not be ing with their peers next week with headteacher Caroline Barlow blaming the school’s rural location. She told Schools Week: A lot of parents don’t want to put their kids on the buses.

title: refugee week celebrate those who
story: NewsRefugee Week: We celebrate those who have gone above and beyond during the pandemicTo mark Refugee Week we celebrate the contributions, resilience and creativity of refugees and asylum seekersShareCommentsByMaryam Qaiser:,  JUN NewsRefugee Week will celebrate the contributions, resilience and creativity of refugees and asylum seekers " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMoving cities to start a new le can be a daunting experience for anyone but imagine being forced to flee your home because of a war. Many refugees and asylum seekers endure long, painful and desperate journeys - travelling by overcrowded boats, cramped lorries or on foot as they trek in search of safety. They don’t want to leave their home countries, their family and friends, but when war breaks out they are left with no other option. Tens of thousands of refugees have arrived in the UK in recent years and the majority have grabbed every opportunity they can to make a better le for themselves in their new homeland by studying, volunteering, working and starting their own businesses. Today marks the first day of Refugee Week  , celebrating the contributions, resilience and creativity of refugees. This yearaposs theme is Imagine, and there will be an online programme of virtual workshops and activities. To mark Refugee Week, weaposve spoken to refugees and asylum seekers, many of whom have been volunteering tirelessly during the Covid- pandemic, about their new lives. Mahmoud Juma is a stall manager at Breadwinners Mahmoud came to England at the age of  without any family or friends. The journey from his home country Sudan took more than a year. Since then, he has been building his confidence and recently enrolled at college to study ESOL. He has also joined Breadwinners - a charity and social enterprise, which sees refugees and asylum seekers sell artisan bread on market stalls across London and has been delivering supplies during the Covid crisis. Mahmoud is now a stall manager for their Victoria Park branch. He is also supported by the Dost Centre, which works with newly-arrived young refugees and newly-arrived migrants.  Mahmoud, , says: “Before joining Breadwinners I didn’t have any confidence, I didn’t know any English, but since running the market I have met many dferent people from dferent cultures. It has helped my confidence and I really enjoy it. When I came to England I felt very lucky, because it was the safest place. It was a very, very painful and tough journey to get here. I faced a lot of challenges. When I first arrived I felt alone and I had no support until I came across some charities including Dost Centre. It was Marian from the Dost Centre who told me about the Breadwinners programme. It is great because I have been able to go camping, play football and make new friends thanks to the support from the centre. I feel this is the beginning of my future. During the Covid- crisis, I have delivered bread to  homes, through our new online orders. I have learnt a lot of skills from Breadwinners which will be valuable for my CV. I have a mentor with Breadwinners who has given me a lot of support, she has been texting me everyday to check I am okay during lockdown. In the future I would like to study and do a job in IT and technology.”  Since Breadwinners was set up in , they have helped  refugees and asylum seekers through their two programmes, Risers and Breadwinners. Risers supports young people who are seeking asylum by giving them work experience as market stall assistants. They also provide training and mentoring so they can build their skills and CV for future employment. The Breadwinners programme supports refugees with newly received status who are struggling to find work by providing opportunities for their first employment in the UK. They work as market stall managers, earning the UK Living Wage, until they are ready to find full time jobs or run their own business. Martin Campos, director at Breadwinners, says: The people we support have something very special, they have gone through so much and faced a lot of challenges, they will cherish every opportunity. It is crazy to see how the people we work with develop and how far they come, from when they first started with us. Some of the people we have supported have gone on to work in nursing, the tourism industry, sales and waitering. Zak Mohammed volunteers to deliver food parcels for Hope charity Zak, who is an asylum seeker, came to England in  from East Africa, but he has chosen not to share his past as he finds it too traumatic. Instead he has chosen to look at the positives in his le and is “thankful” for each day and is passionate about helping others. He is a volunteer with Hope - a Christian charity which works with local churches and community groups to support those in need. The Nottingham-based charity also helps to run food banks in the city. Since the start of the pandemic, Zak has delivered around  food parcels a week for the past two months to residents in need with charity volunteer and friend Julie James. He is also a volunteer with Derbyshire Refugee Solidarity and in the past, he has volunteered with a charity which supports children with disabilities called Umbrella and with Sue Ryder.  Zak, , says: “It feels good to help others, I enjoy volunteering. Everyone is dferent, some people like volunteering and doing something to keep busy, but it doesn’t always suit everyone. When I first came to this country I felt alone and I didn’t know anyone and I had nothing to do, which stressed me out. But now I volunteer with the Hope charity, I volunteer with the Derbyshire Refugee Solidarity and I am a keen runner so I have joined a running club in Derbyshire too. I have been delivering food parcels for Hope for about eight weeks now, it has helped me to continue learning English, I meet dferent people, and I have learnt more about Nottingham too. I don’t have any plans for the future, because I have learnt to take each day at a time and to just be happy.” Julie James, a former teacher of  years, now works in the charity sector focusing on refugees and asylum seekers. Julie, , from Nottingham, said: “Every refugee and asylum seeker who I have worked with has wanted to contribute to society in some way or another, or they’ve looked for paid employment and this needs to be celebrated. Through the charities I work with, refugees and asylum seekers have taken part in fundraising, volunteering and day trips out.”Mazin Saad volunteers to deliver food parcels and has been working at the Covid- testing centre Mazin, who is from Sudan, came to this country in  after a seven month journey. He has lived in Doncaster, South Yorkshire and most recently moved to London and was granted refugee status two years ago. Since the start of the Covid- pandemic, Mazin has been volunteering by delivering food parcels to refugees and asylum seekers in his local community. He also worked at a Covid- testing centre in March and he is now in the process of setting up a charity called Sudanese Solidarity Organisation, alongside his day job as a security officer. Mazin is also a member of the Good Chance Theatre where he regularly takes part in shows and workshops. He recently performed a poem about his journey to England for the theatre’s Migration Matters show.  Mazin, , says: Since the moment I was rescued as an asylum seeker by the Royal Navy, I have felt this country has given me so much that I want to give back. I have so many people to thank. During the pandemic I have been helping refugees and asylum seekers to make sure they have food and any support they need. I am looking to continue this work by setting up a charity called Sudanese Solidarity Organisation, we’re in the process of getting it set up and we have just done the logo. We want to eventually reach out to other countries and help as many people as possible. In this country the gap between refugees and asylum seekers is big, asylum seekers have very little money to live on, they need more support.  Over the years I have volunteered with the likes of British Red Cross and British Heart Foundation. It has helped with my confidence and it has allowed me to understand dferent cultures. I have met many dferent people through my volunteer work and have taken part in many social activities, especially with Good Chance Theatre. It has been great to engage in their workshops and help with fundraising too. Before the Covid- pandemic started, I was studying for a foundation course, which I am hoping to continue, which will hopefully allow me to enrol for an undergraduate course.Teem Khan, is an NHS worker, who also has his own fashion brand. He has been making masks. Teem, who is from East Africa, came to this country as a student in . He studied Travel and Tourism. After a y and challenging four year process, Teem went from being an asylum seeker to being granted refugee status  months ago. Teem, who lives in London, has recently started working for the NHS as a warehouse supervisor. Teem has recently started his own fashion brand, with the help of TERN - an organisation which helps refugees start a business. Teem has been making masks during the pandemic. Teem, , says: The process to become a refugee has ruined my mental health, it has been very traumatic, I was not able to work which was very hard for me. It still affects my anxiety today. However I had a lot of support from people, charities and organisations. I have recently started my own fashion brand, but I have had to put this on hold due to the panademic. I am now in week five of my new job. I have also been making masks in my own time. For every mask that I sell, I donate one to an asylum seeker. Asylum Seekers donapost have a lot of money to live on from the Government and buying a mask is probably the last thing on their mind. The masks are colourful, some have sequins, some are plain and some are made from denim, I have also used fabric with printed superheroes on including Toy Story.

story: NewsSchoolboy left with huge gash on head after ft tall white swan launches at himWARNING: GRAPHIC IMAGE Jacob Gregory, , was hauled from the water with blood streaming from his head after the frightening attack by the huge birdShareCommentsByJim HardyTanveer MannDeputy News Editor:,  JUN NewsJacob Gregory was having a picnic when the attack happened " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn eight-year-old boy was left with a deep gash to his head after a ft tall white swan began attacking him. Jacob Gregory was having a picnic with his mum Sophie Hall, , and her partner Alex Conduit, , his daughter Bella, six, and their daughter Lily,  months, when the swan flew at him as he enjoyed a swim. The youngster was hauled from the water with blood streaming from his head after the attack by the huge bird which viciously pecked him. He was only saved when his brave mum ed fully-clothed into a river to rescue him. The Year  pupil at Bitham Brook Primary School in Westbury, Wilts, was taken to Frome Community Hospital with a deep wound in his head and is now recovering at home. Sophie Hall, of Oldfield Park, Westbury, said they chose a spot beside the River Wylye at picturesque Hanging Langford a few miles from their home. Jacob was playing in the river in his rubber ring along with a few other children in the water. Out of nowhere, a swan came charging towards him, and mounted him, flapping constantly, and attacked. Blood was pouring from his head. My partner and I ed into the water fully clothed to rescue my son and attempted to deter the swan from further attacking him. After dragging him from the water we were shocked to see he was covered in blood from a gash the swan had made on the back of his head. We took him to the minor injuries unit at Frome Community Hospital where he was treated and is now on medication for the wound. After the swan had been scared off by us, he then went up-stream and attacked another lady. My son was very shaken up but is very proud that he survived an animal attack and enjoys telling his story to people. At the hospital, nursing staff cleaned the wound but were reluctant to glue it closed because of fears that it might be contaminated with germs from the swan. Sophie said: They gave us a week’s supply of antibiotics and some special cream to put on it. The River Wylye between Hanging Langford and Steeple Langford is a popular picnic spot for families as there is parking opposite. Adults and children are able to swim and play in the river and afterwards sunbathe and dry off on the grassy river bank.

A queue of people also waited outside Nike Town on Oxford Street shortly after am, ahead of the storeaposs opening at am.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThese are the first pictures of a black man who was fatally shot by US police outside a drive-through restaurant, sparking a new wave of anti-racist protests. Rayshard Brooks died in hospital on Friday night after a scuffle with officers outside a Wendyaposs in Georgia, having allegedly failed a sobriety test and resisting arrest after falling asleep in his car. The -year-old was a father to three girls and also had a stepson, WSB-TV reports. Investigators tonight released footage of the struggle with Atlanta Police that preceded him being shot and killed, which comes only weeks after the death of George Floyd in police custody in Minneapolis. It has sparked fresh demonstrations in the streets of Atlanta, which saw the Wendyaposs where Mr Brooks died lit on fire by protesters on Saturday night.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at www.mirror email  Images on local television showed the restaurant in flames while an anti-racist march has also completely shut down the Interstate  Highway. Mr Floydaposs death has sparked three weeks of widespread protests against racial discrimination, and in some cases violent clashes with police and right-wing counter-protesters, across the US and around the world.The Georgia Bureau of Investigation has now launched a probe into Mr Brooksapos death. In a statement given to CNN, it says police were called to the restaurant at around .pm on Friday after a man was found to be asleep in his vehicle, blocking the drive-through lane and forcing other customers to drive around him. The GBI says police then gave Mr Brooks a sobriety test, which he failed, leading to the scuffle.  Attorneys L. Chris Stewart and Justin Miller, who are now representing Mr Brooksapos family, released the images on Saturday night. According to broadcaster CBS, he had spent the evening of his death celebrating his eldest daughteraposs birthday. The fatal shooting led to Atlantaaposs police chief, Erika Shields, resigning on Saturday. Shieldsapos statement said: For more than two decades, I have served alongside some of the finest women and men in the Atlanta Police Department. Out of a deep and abiding love for this City and this department, I offered to step aside as police chief. APD has my full support, and Mayor Bottoms has my support on the future direction of this department. I have faith in the Mayor, and it is time for the city to move forward and build trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. The Atlanta police involved in the shooting have been criticised for the use of firearms, given that Mr Brooks appears to have only had a Taser. The cityaposs mayor, Keisha Lance Bottoms, said: I do not believe that this was a justied use of deadly force and have called for the immediate termination of the officer. US politician Stacey Abrams, a former Georgia political candidate, is among those who have called for restrictions on police use of deadly force.Commenting on Twitter, she said: A Taser is not a deadly weapon. A gun is. Adrenaline and irritation are not the same as mortal fear. Running away should not be punishable by death. Public safety must mean the public is safe. All of us. And Jen Jordan, a Democratic State Senator for Georgiaaposs th District, wrote: Asleep in his car. Thataposs why police were called. Now he is dead after being shot three times in the back as he was running away. #RayshardBrooksshould not be dead. Authorities have not yet released the names of the two officers, who were both white. A video taken from a nearby car, and released by the GBI, shows Mr Brooks on the ground outside his car, struggling with two officers.

title: inside abandoned house caked dirt
story: NewsInside abandoned house caked in dirt and rubble that transports you back in timeCoronation Street star Jake Parr spotted the house hidden between the trees on Google Maps and had to go and investigate as part of his photography project AbandonedShareCommentsByLouise ElliottPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  JUN NewsThe exterior of the house is magnicent and has so much potential" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailActor Jake Parr discovered an incredible house which had been abandoned in Cheshire. Jake, , from Manchester often goes in search of the weirdest, and most wonderful buildings and structures as part of his photography project aposAbandoned.aposBut he is best known for his appearances on a number of television shows like Coronation Street, Judge Rinderaposs Crime Stories and Fast and Furious  - which is yet to be released, reported Stoke-On-Trent Live. Before lockdown Jake went in search of the Crewe property after spotting it on Google Maps.Hidden behind an array of trees and overgrown bushes was the abandoned property - and it did not disappoint. He said: I never reveal the exact location of the places I find but this one was near Crewe. The sort of places I find are all old and abandoned so I never know what I am going to find. This house was as though someone just left and never came back. There was a pair of shoes and a sewing machine, and beds still in the house - plus an enormous Quality Street tin which was much bigger than the ones we get now!  The exterior of the property, albeit run-down, shows so much potential with its grand structure and columns surrounding the front door. Upon entering the property, the wallpaper in the hallway was peeling and the pretty geometric design of the floor was barely noticeable beneath the dirt.  Among the dirt and rubble were a number of books and magazines lying open - including a page from the Daily Star dated August ,  - as well as a sewing machine, a pair of menaposs smart shoes and a large tin of Quality Street. Upstairs, you can expect to see one of the bedrooms filled with broken furniture as well as branches pushing their way through the window. In the garden, other than the caravan, Jake spotted an array of car parts strewn around, and a mattress. This is a hobby for me, says Jake.

title: prince harry loves cheeky nandos
story: NewsPrince Harry loves a cheeky Nandos - but his order will upset many peoplePrince Harry and brother Prince William both love a Nandos, and have been spotted popping in for a quick bite to eat on several occasionsShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsWho doesnt love Nandos  " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrince Harry gave up a lot when he packed his bags and waved goodbye to the UK - leaving his royal title behind him - in favour of a new le in LA.While we hope heaposs enjoying spending time in the sunshine with we Meghan Markle and son Archie, thereaposs one thing he might be missing - Nandoaposs.Believe it or not, Harry is said to be a huge fan of everyoneaposs favourite peri-peri chicken chain, but they wonapost have any restaurants in LA. Both Harry and his brother Prince William love popping in for a cheeky Nandoaposs, and theyaposve talked about it numerous times. Prince Harry was introduced to the South African chain a few years back by his personal protection officer and has been spotted at the chain several times, including a midnight visit to the restaurant in Fulham Broadway, south west London in .Harry, who was  at the time, forked out £. on his takeaway dinner for himself and a friend at .pm on a Tuesday night. Two members of the Prince’s personal security sat patiently behind him while he waited more than  minutes for his Portuguese inspired grub to be prepared. Harry was seen fidgeting with his mobile phone and making animated hand gestures to his mate as the pair killed time to distract themselves from hunger. A stunned onlooker said: “It was surreal. He was very charming and politely refused a member of staff who approached him for a picture. I was gobsmacked to see him.” Another witness added: “Moments after he left the restaurant clutching his dinner in a paper bag a member of staff jumped on the bench the Harry was sitting on and shouted: “I’m on the Prince’s throne!’ Nobody could believe what happened.”  However not everyone will be particularly impressed by what the royal ordered from the Nandoaposs menu. He ordered a pitta with extra cheese and a side of creamy mash, along with a double chicken wrap with chips. He also got a soft drink and bottle of water. However the pitta was lemon and herb, the chainaposs mildest offering which many people see as a terrible order. It’s unclear whether Harry – who wore a green polo shirt, denim jeans and a baseball cap partially disguising his face according to a witness - paid full price for the grub or took advantage of the  per cent discount the chicken-chain offers to military personnel.After picking up their order Harry, who was dating Cressida Bonas  at the time, and his pal casually exited through the car park which is connected with the building.

story: Jonny Hayes was a rough diamond when he arrived in Scotland.And his former Inverness coach Maurice Malpas has taken pleasure and pride in watching the shine and polish put on the Dundee United target over the past decade.The Tannadice legend – Terry Butcher’s No at Caley Thistle – remembers the -year-old Irishman’s early days on these shores with fondness.The managerial duo knew they had a talent on their hands, but one that would occasionally frustrate them with his profligacy in wide positions and needed time to adapt to their training demands in the Highlands.Incredibly, Hayes – who had played very little senior football at that stage of his career – scored  goals in  games in all competitions as Inverness clinched the   First Division title.Malpas, , told Tele Sport: “We got Jonny as a raw kid and we went from one extreme to the other at times.“Jonny was recommended to us from one of our guys down south and he came up for pre-season.“He hadn’t played that many first-team games and hadn’t been put under any pressure.“He wasn’t sure what it was going to be like with us at Inverness and we weren’t sure what he was going to be like.“The first thing you noticed was his sheer pace. We knew we needed to improve his fitness.“Once we got him fit – we needed to get him up to scratch and keep him playing at the same time – and got into his head in terms of how we played, he was great for us.“He was brilliant at taking the ball, getting us up the park and running past defenders, his pace was a major asset.“I didn’t have a lot of hair at the time but I still lost a bit because he would drive you bananas at times with some of the silly things he’d do in good positions.“It goes without saying that he’s matured well beyond that now. He might have lost a bit of pace in recent years but he is a seasoned campaigner.“Back then he was desperate to come up to Scotland and play games.“The big thing we sold him on was the area, the lestyle – the tranquillity up here compared to the hurly-burly down south.“We told him he could get himself on the TV, sell himself in the big games and we were the type of club thatsomeone came in for you with a decent offer, you’d have the option to go.”Hayes – who started out at Reading – eventually left for Aberdeen in  after three years with Inverness.Over  games in five seasons and a League Cup winners’ medal in the Granite City followed before he clinched a £ million move to Celtic.The winger struggled to establish himself as a Hoops regular but he started several crucial games for the Scottish champions, including the  Scottish Cup final triumph over Hearts and the stunning Europa League victory over Lazio in Rome last November.Two months earlier he grabbed the second goal in the Old Firm derby as Neil Lennon’s side beat Rangers - at Ibrox.Hayes’ Parkhead exit – which has also led to interest from his former employers at Pittodrie – came less than two weeks after he picked up his third title medal in three campaigns with the club.Malpas said: “I thought Jonny would’ve got another contract at Celtic and that he would happily have stayed.“But maybe they’re trimming their squad a bit to get players in and maybe there wasn’t going to be the chance to play as many games next season.“He certainly didn’t let Celtic down when he was called upon.“For United, though, good on them for trying to sign Jonny. They’re clearly thinking about the right players and I think that’s the type of player they need.“He’s experienced and he’s played at a very good level. He’s still got pace, he can play in more than one position and he’s good in a dressing room.“I thinkyou were struggling in the middle of the pitch he could do a job there as well.“You’d never say he was the best defender, but he never seems to get a doing from the wide players he plays against.“Sometimes you think he isn’t the best at beating people yet he always seems to get crosses in.“For us at Inverness he was great at getting the ball in the box and created a lot of goals for guys like Adam Rooney.”The former United captain saw a transformation in Hayes during his time with the Dons.He added: “I’ve followed Jonny’s career for years and hoped he would do well.“He was great for us and did everything we asked. He’s one of the many guys you like to think you’ve helped a bit.“Jonny’s really matured and looked after his fitness. At Aberdeen he was playing under a bit more pressure in front of a more demanding crowd and that helped him make the move to Celtic.“He was a cheeky chappie when we had him –he got a bit of stick, he’d give a bit back. Some things used to affect him but I could see a dference at Aberdeen, he’d outgrown that and he could handle that.“We had a great group at Inverness. When we went in, we only kept three or four players and started again.“Graeme Shinnie was one of the kids that was there and he has developed into a right good player as well.“These guys would run through a wall for you and they were a joy to work with.“We didn’t have great facilities but these guys wanted to learn, they wanted to work and they had a great attitude.”Dundee United appoint senior club representative to liaise with Terrors fan groups" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee-united-fan-groups-liaison embed # secretNdKFhlJe" data-secret"NdKFhlJe" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: were making significant yet necessary changes hotel boss sets out plans for life after coronavirus
story: A Dundee hotel has released its plans for reopening once the lockdown rules ease.Dundee’s Malmaison hotel, based close to the city’s Waterfront is introducing operational changes in the hope that it can continue to deliver an exceptional service while still observing guidelines when travel restrictions are finally relaxed.Scott Harper, chief operating officer of both Malmaison and Hotel du Vin which has a site in St Andrews, explained the hotel’s new procedures.He said: “As we prepare for restrictions to ease for the hospitality sector, the health and safety of all guests and staff remains a core priority for Malmaison.“We’re making signicant, yet necessary, changes to our services and the operation of Malmaison in order to keep our commitment of delivering the best possible experience for guests, while operating in accordance with the latest guidance from the government and local health authorities.“In preparation, we’re marking out safe distances to ensure social distancing can be observed by guests and employees throughout our hotels.“We have invested in protection screens, located at reception desks and other key points of interaction, as well as PPE for our staff. vw, px"  “Compulsory sanitation stations are being installed, to ensure hand hygiene is maintained.“There will be clear signage throughout the hotel advising guests of our safety precautions. Personal interaction and touch points will be kept to a minimum, including implementing cashless payments only.“The big priority will be increasing the scope, depth and frequency of cleaning throughout the hotel, including key touch points, such as lt buttons and door handles, as well as fully sanitising guest rooms ready for their arrival. We are utilising the very latest anti-viral cleaning techniques.“And our breakfast and dinner service offerings have been adapted, to avoid cross-contamination, while maintaining our high standards and love of all things food and drink.“Our rooms have been decluttered including the removal of the mini-bar contents and most collateral, to assist in maintaining hygiene levels.“We’re confident that the changes we’re making exceed current health and safety standards so that guests will be able to stay, wine and dine with a peace of mind.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles. blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: aberdeen primary school pupils take part in light the north activities
story: School pupils have taken part in activities inspired by a charity lighthouse scheme.Clan Cancer Support was due to run its Light the North campaign in September however it has been postponed until next year due to the coronavirus pandemic.Lighthouse sculptures would have popped up in ious locations across the north-east during the event carried out in partnership with Wild In Art, the group behind the Oor Wullie Big Bucket and Dolphin Sculpture Trail. vw, px"  It was also running an education programme called Little Lights, with a number of primary schools and youth groups taking part.One of those selected was primary one pupils at St Joseph#s RC School.Teacher Stephanie Scott said: #P at St Joseph’s were selected to take part in the Light the North project organised by Wild in Art and CLAN through the Little lights education programme.#The trail has been delayed due to COVID but schools were encouraged to do the projectthey were able.#Although the children are currently learning from home, they are learning all about our environment and the seaside population.Inspired by the lighthouses, they began to find out what you can find at the seaside and how it has changed over the years, as well as researching sea creatures and how they can be affected by litter at the beach and in the sea. vw, px"  They also took part in their own litter picks at the seasidethey were able to do so or near their homes, and wrote instructions for others to allow them to learn how to pick up litter safely.And they made marine monsters out of single use materials, the type you might find on a litter pick.Each of the pupils were then tasked with designing their own colourful lighthouses reflecting what they had learned over the project about the side, with one pupil#s design chosen.It will be transferred onto the D model, which will be used for the Lighthouse Trail next year.The children learned about how lighthouses are viewed as a beacon of hope, which linked in with Clan Cancer Support, which is often a beacon of hope for families affected by cancer.Working together, they took part in fundraising activities and raised £.Stephanie added: #To finish the topic, the children organised fundraising activities to raise money for CLAN.#Some did sponsored bike rides, others sold baking or art products. They raised over £.#The P teachers are very proud of all they have achieved in relation to this project even with learning at home, and are very appreciative of the parents for their support.#For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: done aberdeen trust sets up covid 19 fund for community
story: An Aberdeen trust has set up a new Covid- fund to support members of a community during the pandemic.The Aberdeen Bangladeshi Welfare Trust launched its support grant earlier this month.Anyone who is from a Bangladeshi background and is resident in Aberdeen or Aberdeenshire is welcome to applythey are in need of assistance due to the coronavirus pandemic.Grants of up to £ for utility bills, up to £ for food and up to £ for children’s clothing are being made for those who are suffering hardship, but not eligible for other Covid- related support.Successful applicants will be those who do not have access to sufficient savings or other sources of income to meet basic needs during this time.Farhadur Chowdhury, secretary of the Aberdeen Bangladeshi Welfare Trust , said: #ABWT was formed in January  to support the Bangladeshi community in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire. We are grateful to Lord Provost#s Hardship Fund and AVA Funding for extending their support towards our community by funding this project.#Since January last year, ABWT organised many cultural and sports events including Bangla New Year Celebration, Annual Badminton Tournament, Victory Day Celebration, Annual Picnic for the Bangladeshi community in Aberdeen and Aberdeenshire.#We aim to continue to work for Bangladeshi community to improve their living condition and promoting cultural ersity in Aberdeen.#For more information on the fund and to apply, visit https:bit.ly AkIvHFor as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: work on new aberdeen science hub to start in summer
story: Work to create a new bio-therapeutics hub in Aberdeen will now begin in the summer after being delayed due to coronavirus.The £ million centre aims to double the number of le sciences companies in the north-east and will be based at Foresterhill Health Campus.It will offer flexible working space to tenants and includes office space, incubator labs and access to meeting rooms and conference facilities, allowing for collaboration between industry, researchers and clinicians.The initiative, Bio Aberdeen, is being delivered by the Opportunity North EastLe Sciences sector board in collaboration with Aberdeen University, Robert Gordon University, NHS Grampian and Scottish Enterprise.It will help academics, clinicians, companies and researchers to collaborate, innovate and commercialise therapies, products and solutions for modern health challenges.And it will provide a dynamic, collaborative environment with business support programmes for the incubation and growth of start-up and early-stage le sciences companies.Work was originally planned to begin getting underway in April after plans were approved, however construction had to be delayed due to the Covid- crisis.Prof Stephen Logan, chair of Opportunity North East’s le sciences sector board and BioAberdeen Ltd, the new company formed to deliver BioHub, said: “We have revised the planned start date for the construction of BioHub because of the impact of coronavirus on the construction sector.#As project lead, ONE is working closely with the project partners in NHS Grampian and University of Aberdeen to agree an updated construction start date and programme.#We aim to begin work on the Foresterhill Health Campus in the summer with BioHub opening at the end of .”The five-storey high building is hoped to have a glass-led cafe and work spaces at the main entrance, as well as secure access and car parking at the site.The , sq ft facility will include accommodation for start-ups and established companies, space for collaboration, and shared facilities for events, small conferences and networking.The new plan for opening the BioHub is in keeping with the original goal of having the first phase of the development open next year.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSir,A big thank you to whoever has tidied up Ardrishaig Community Garden, mown the grass and repaired and painted the fences.Such a peaceful place to call into while out exercising. I can#t wait for the day I can go back there to sit and contemplate, enjoy the views and read or paint.Cheryl Ratclfe-Nye, Ardrishaig.Sir,I would like to thank all the telecommunications workers in Scotland, many of whom have been designated key workers, for how they’ve responded to the coronavirus outbreak.They are providing essential support to the NHS and keeping all of us connected during this dficult time.From the engineers going out to keep our broadband and mobile networks connected, to the vital contact centre staff helping customers when they need it most, they deserve recognition.My colleagues, working with the Scottish Government and NHS, worked quickly to provide the temporary NHS Louisa Jordan hospital in Glasgow with communications. They are doing the same to support other temporary NHS services across Scotland.Our people have worked around the clock with health boards across the country to offer new, technical solutions to help frontline health workers get on with their jobs during this crisis.Our frontline staff in contact centres across Scotland – including Aberdeen, Dundee, Glasgow and Greenock – have risen to this unprecedented challenge. We’ve received a huge surge of customers asking for faster connections to help with home working, home schooling and running their businesses remotely.These colleagues – most of whom can now work from home when they want to – have performed a critical role keeping our customers, including frontline health workers and vulnerable people, connected.The people in our two  contact centres in Scotland are also playing a critical role, answering lesaving emergency calls.I couldn’t be more proud of how my colleagues have responded to these challenges and their desire to help us all through this crisis.Jane Wood, BT Group director in Scotland, Edinburgh.COVID- is seriously not a jokeGlobally kills thousands of folkYou start coughing, you can#t breatheWithout a respirator, this earth you#ll leaveSocial distancing is now in placeKeep two metres apart, not face to faceWash your hands frequently and well hours on surfaces it can dwellShop infrequently, for essentials onlyDon#t mix with othersyou#re lonelyKeep in touch by text and phoneDon#t put yourself at risk, stay aloneIt#s hoped soon this contagion will peakThen we canto normal, so to speakDon#t travel to other towns by carIt can spread the virus near and farSports, socialising and most work on holdThe alternative could cause damage untoldSupport the NHS, essential workers and neighboursThen we#ll defeat this virus by all our laboursDugald MacGilp, Lochgilphead.Sir,We are looking for people who have the passion to bring communities together, believe in the power of co-operation and who hold the well-being of their community at the forefront of their mind.The successful #Member Pioneers# will receive full training and business support as they help groups and iniduals during the coronavirus pandemic and beyond. The pioneers will cover three wide areas: one based around Longrow in Campbeltown, another around The Avenue in Inveraray and a third around Bishopton Road, Lochgilphead.The new positions form part of a drive to recruit , pioneers across the country. Existing pioneers are currently involved in a wide range of activities including co-ordinating food drives and offering personal support to those unable to leave their homes.This has never been more important than now.The local area has so many strengths and we want to help communities be as resilient as possible against the new challenges posed by COVID-. The new pioneers will spearhead our efforts, support great causes and think up new ideas.To apply to be a Member Pioneer, visit jobs.coop member-pioneers. Roles are  hours a month. Closing date for both positions is Wednesday May .Russell Gill, head of co-operative and local engagement at Co-op.
